meanings: To give up being a leader or in charge of something, like when a king or queen decides to stop ruling.
examples: The king decided to abdicate his throne because he wanted to travel the world and explore new places.
When the class president felt overwhelmed with responsibilities, she chose to abdicate her position and let someone else take charge.
In the game, if a player abdicates their turn, they lose the chance to move until the next round.
The queen in the story had to abdicate her crown to save her kingdom from a terrible fate.
After realizing he was too busy with sports, Jake decided to abdicate his role as team captain for the season.

meanings: To get rid of something completely, like a rule or a practice, so that it no longer exists.
examples: The school decided to abolish the rule that banned students from bringing their favorite books to class.
In history class, we learned that some countries worked hard to abolish unfair laws that treated people badly.
My parents want to abolish the habit of leaving lights on when no one is in the room to save energy.
The community came together to abolish littering in the park by organizing a big cleanup day.
After discussing it with the teacher, the students voted to abolish homework on Fridays so they could enjoy their weekends.

meanings: Something that is really silly or makes no sense at all, like wearing a winter coat in the summer.
examples: It’s absurd to think that a fish could win a race against a cheetah in the wild.
When my teacher said we would have a test on a Saturday, I thought that was absurd!
The idea that a dog could learn to ride a bicycle is pretty absurd, but it would be funny to see!
My brother believes that aliens are hiding under our bed, which sounds absolutely absurd to me.
In the story, the king decided to wear his crown on his feet, and everyone thought it was absurd!

meanings: To speed up or make something go faster, like when a car drives quicker or when you run faster in a race.
examples: When you push the gas pedal in a car, it will accelerate and go faster down the road.
In science class, we learned that when the sun heats the air, it can make wind accelerate and move more quickly.
During the race, I tried to accelerate so I could catch up to my friend who was ahead of me.
If you practice your soccer skills every day, you will accelerate your improvement and become a better player.
The rocket was designed to accelerate into space, reaching high speeds as it left Earth’s atmosphere.

meanings: To access something means to get into a place or to find and use information, like when you open a door to go inside or look something up on the computer.
examples: To access the library, we need to show our student ID cards to the librarian at the front desk.
I can access my favorite games on the tablet after I finish my homework and chores.
During our science project, we had to access the internet to find information about different animals.
The teacher explained how to access the online classroom to see our assignments and grades.
When we visit the museum, we can access all the interesting exhibits about dinosaurs and space!

meanings: To make room for someone or something, so they can fit in or be comfortable.
examples: Our teacher rearranged the desks to accommodate all the students for the big group project.
During our camping trip, we needed to find a place that could accommodate our entire team of explorers.
The library has special rooms that can accommodate kids who want to study together or read quietly.
To accommodate everyone at the birthday party, we made sure there were enough snacks and games for all the guests.
The soccer coach decided to accommodate more players on the team by creating a second practice group after school.

meanings: To accomplish something means to finish a task or reach a goal that you have worked hard for, like completing a school project or winning a game.
examples: I worked hard on my science project, and I was proud to accomplish my goal of getting an 'A' on it.
During soccer practice, I practiced my kicks so I could accomplish scoring a goal in our next game.
With teamwork, we can accomplish our class's goal of reading 1,000 books by the end of the school year.
After weeks of practice, I finally accomplished my dream of finishing the entire book series I loved.
I set a goal to learn how to ride my bike without training wheels, and I was excited to accomplish it on my own!

meanings: Accurate means something that is exactly right or true, like when you answer a math problem correctly.
examples: The teacher said my math answers were accurate, which made me feel proud of my hard work.
When I read the book, I found that the map was accurate and showed all the important places in the story.
To win the game, you need to be accurate when aiming for the target with your bow and arrow.
In science class, we learned that an accurate thermometer helps us measure temperature correctly.
My mom took an accurate measurement of the ingredients to make the cookies turn out just right.

meanings: To get used to something by doing it often or experiencing it many times. For example, when you practice riding a bike, you become accustomed to balancing on it.
examples: It took me a few weeks to accustom myself to the new school and make friends.
My puppy needs to accustom himself to wearing a collar before we can take him for walks.
When I started learning the violin, it took time to accustom my fingers to the strings.
My teacher helped us accustom our minds to solve tricky math problems by practicing every day.
As we camped in the woods, we had to accustom ourselves to sleeping in a tent instead of a bed.

meanings: To make someone feel very sad, hurt, or troubled. For example, when someone is sick, it can afflict them by causing pain or discomfort.
examples: Sometimes, a cold can afflict us, making it hard to concentrate on our homework.
When the heavy rain began to afflict the picnic, we quickly moved under the shelter to stay dry.
The mean bully tried to afflict fear in others, but we stood together and supported each other.
If too many weeds afflict the garden, the flowers won't get enough sunlight to grow strong.
In the story, the dragon's curse would afflict the village until a brave hero arrived to save them.

meanings: Showing strong feelings or actions that can seem angry or mean; it's like when someone is ready to fight instead of being friendly.
examples: The dog barked aggressively at the stranger walking by our house, making us feel a little scared.
In soccer practice, some players can be aggressive when trying to steal the ball from their opponents.
When the bear felt threatened, it became aggressive and growled to warn us to stay away.
During the game, my teammate played aggressively, always trying to score points for our team.
In the story, the dragon was aggressive and scared the villagers until a brave knight saved them.

meanings: Agony is a very strong feeling of pain or sadness that makes you feel really uncomfortable, like when you hurt yourself badly or feel heartbroken.
examples: After falling off his bike, Jake felt a sharp agony in his knee that made it hard to walk.
During the scary movie, Sarah cried out in agony when the monster jumped out unexpectedly.
When I lost my favorite video game, I felt a deep agony because I had worked so hard to win it.
After studying all night for the big test, Lisa was in agony from being so tired the next day.
When the team lost the championship game, the players were in agony, feeling sad about their hard work not paying off.

meanings: Being alert means paying close attention to what is happening around you, like when you're in school and listening carefully to your teacher. It helps you notice important things and stay safe.
examples: During the game, I stayed alert so I could catch the ball when it was thrown my way.
My teacher said we need to be alert in class to listen for important instructions about our project.
When hiking in the woods, it’s important to be alert for any wild animals that might be nearby.
While reading the mystery book, I had to stay alert to notice all the clues hidden in the story.
At the science fair, I was alert to see how my classmates presented their cool projects and experiments.

meanings: Altitude is how high something is above the ground or sea level, like when you climb a mountain and get really high up in the sky.
examples: When we climbed the mountain, we noticed that the altitude made it harder to breathe.
The altitude of our school is quite high, so we can see the whole town from the roof.
During our science project, we learned that planes fly at a high altitude above the clouds.
In gym class, we talked about how running at a high altitude can make athletes stronger.
While hiking, we saw different plants and animals that live at various altitudes on the mountain.

meanings: Having plenty of something; enough to meet your needs and still have some left over.
examples: The recipe called for ample flour, so we made a big batch of cookies to share with everyone.
During the science fair, my project had ample information to impress the judges and my classmates.
The library had ample books on dinosaurs, so I was able to find everything I needed for my report.
After the game, we had ample snacks left over, so everyone got to enjoy some extra treats.
My grandma's garden has ample flowers, making it the perfect spot for a picnic with my friends.

meanings: An ancestor is a family member who lived a long time ago, like a great-grandparent or great-great-grandparent, from whom you are related. They are part of your family's history.
examples: My teacher told us that our ancestors came from different countries and brought unique traditions to our families.
In history class, we learned that our ancestors faced many challenges to build the lives we have today.
When I looked at my family tree, I could see pictures of my ancestors from long ago, like great-great-grandparents.
My mom says that learning about our ancestors helps us understand where we come from and who we are.
During the school project, I discovered that one of my ancestors was a famous explorer who traveled the world!

meanings: Full of energy and excitement, like when you're really happy or having fun. It can also mean something that is made to look like it's moving, like in cartoons.
examples: The animated movie we watched in class made us all laugh and cheer for the characters.
During art class, my friend drew an animated dragon that seemed to breathe fire with its colors.
At the science fair, the animated presentation about space made everyone excited to learn more about the planets.
When we played the animated video game, it felt like we were really on an adventure together.
The animated stories in the book made the characters come to life and kept me reading all night.

meanings: Feeling worried or nervous about something that might happen, like before a test or a big event.
examples: I felt anxious before my big presentation in class because I wanted to do well and impress my teacher.
When I tried out for the soccer team, I was anxious about whether I would make it or not.
My little brother gets anxious when he has to speak in front of the class, even if he knows the material.
I was anxious about my science project because I wanted to make sure everything worked perfectly for the science fair.
Before the school play, I was anxious backstage, but once I started acting, I felt much better.

meanings: Approximate means a number or amount that is close to the real one but not exactly the same, like saying you have about 10 candies when you actually have 9 or 11.
examples: The approximate number of candies in the jar was around fifty, but we didn't count them exactly.
When we measured the length of the table, we found it to be an approximate six feet long.
For our science project, we needed an approximate weight of the rock, so we guessed it was about two pounds.
During the math quiz, I made an approximate answer for the last question because I ran out of time.
The approximate time it takes to finish the book is about two weeks if I read a little every day.

meanings: Aroma is a nice smell that comes from things like food, flowers, or spices, making us want to take a deep breath and enjoy it.
examples: The aroma of freshly baked cookies filled the kitchen, making everyone excited for dessert.
When we walked through the garden, the sweet aroma of blooming flowers made us smile.
As we cooked dinner together, the aroma of garlic and onions made our mouths water.
During our picnic, the aroma of the sandwiches mixed with the fresh scent of the grass around us.
In art class, the aroma of paint and clay inspired us to create colorful masterpieces.

meanings: To ascend means to go up, like climbing a ladder or riding an elevator to a higher floor.
examples: As the hot air balloon began to ascend, we could see the entire city spread out below us.
In science class, we learned how rockets ascend into space, leaving Earth behind to explore the stars.
When the mountain climbers reach the top, they will ascend the steep path carefully to avoid slipping.
During the school assembly, the principal announced that the students who won the contest would ascend the stage to collect their prizes.
As the sun began to rise in the morning, it seemed to ascend slowly over the horizon, filling the sky with light.

meanings: To assemble means to put things together or gather items in one place, like when you build a toy or put together a puzzle.
examples: We need to assemble all the puzzle pieces before we can see the complete picture.
In science class, we will assemble the model of the solar system using different sized balls.
During art time, we will assemble our supplies, like paints and brushes, to start our project.
The coach asked us to assemble on the field so we could practice our soccer drills as a team.
At the library, we will assemble our favorite books to create a special display for everyone to see.

meanings: To assign means to give someone a specific job or task to complete, like when a teacher asks you to work on a project or a friend asks you to help with a game.
examples: The teacher will assign a special project to each student to help us learn about different animals.
My coach decided to assign positions for the soccer game, so everyone knew where to play.
During art class, our instructor will assign each of us a different color to use for our paintings.
At home, my mom will assign chores to me and my brother, so we can keep the house clean.
In science class, the teacher will assign partners for a fun experiment about how plants grow.

meanings: To connect or think about two things together, like when you remember a friend when you see their favorite toy.
examples: When I think of summer, I always associate it with swimming and ice cream on hot days.
In science class, we learned to associate plants with sunlight and water for them to grow healthy.
My teacher said we can associate certain colors with different feelings, like blue for calm and red for excitement.
When I hear the song from my favorite movie, I always associate it with happy memories of watching it with my family.
In history, we associate important events with the people who made a difference, like Martin Luther King Jr. and his dream for equality.

meanings: To believe something is true without checking if it really is, like thinking your friend will come to your birthday party just because you invited them.
examples: I assume that if I study hard for the test, I will get a good grade.
When I saw the dark clouds, I began to assume that it would rain soon.
If my dog is barking, I assume that someone is at the door or outside.
I assume my mom will make my favorite dinner because it's my birthday today.
When my friend didn't come to school, I assumed she was sick and hoped she would feel better soon.

meanings: Able to be used or gotten; something that is ready for you to take or use when you need it.
examples: The library has many books available for us to read during our quiet time in class.
My mom said that the new video game will be available for download next week.
At the science fair, I learned that solar panels are available to help power homes with sunlight.
The coach told us that extra practice time is available after school for those who want to improve their skills.
There are plenty of snacks available in the kitchen if you get hungry while doing your homework.

meanings: An avalanche is a big slide of snow, ice, and rocks that rushes down a mountain very quickly. It can happen when too much snow builds up and suddenly breaks loose, just like if you pushed a pile of sn...
examples: While skiing in the mountains, I learned that an avalanche can happen if too much snow builds up on a slope.
In our science class, we watched a video showing how an avalanche can occur when the snow gets too heavy and slides down the mountain.
During our field trip to the snowy hills, our guide told us about the dangers of an avalanche and how to stay safe.
In the book I read, the characters had to escape an avalanche while exploring a snowy cave in the mountains.
When we built a snow fort, I imagined what it would be like if an avalanche came and covered everything in snow!

meanings: A banquet is a big, special meal where many people come together to celebrate something important, like a birthday or a holiday. It often has lots of delicious food and drinks.
examples: Our school held a banquet to celebrate the winners of the science fair, and everyone was excited to see the projects.
For my birthday, my family organized a special banquet with my favorite foods, and all my friends came to celebrate with me.
The king invited everyone in the village to a grand banquet to honor the brave knights who had saved the kingdom.
After the big soccer tournament, the team enjoyed a delicious banquet with pizza and cake to celebrate their victory together.
In the story, the animals planned a banquet in the forest to thank the wise old owl for sharing his knowledge with them.

meanings: Barren" means land that is very dry and has no plants growing on it. It's like a sandy desert where nothing can grow.
examples: The barren desert stretched for miles, with only a few cacti surviving in the hot sun.
In science class, we learned that barren land can be difficult for plants to grow because it lacks nutrients.
After the storm, the once green field looked barren, with only mud and debris left behind.
The barren mountains had no trees or flowers, making them look empty and sad.
During our hiking trip, we saw a barren area where nothing seemed to grow, not even grass.

meanings: To bask means to lie down or sit in a warm place, like the sun, and enjoy the feeling of heat on your skin. It's like soaking up sunshine on a nice day!
examples: After swimming in the cool pool, we laid on the warm deck to bask in the sunshine.
During our picnic in the park, we decided to bask under the big oak tree and enjoy our sandwiches.
The puppy loved to bask in the sunlight that streamed through the window while napping on the rug.
On sunny days, I like to bask on the beach with my family and build sandcastles.
After finishing our science project, we took a break to bask in the warm sun on the school lawn.

meanings: To betray someone means to be untrustworthy by sharing their secrets or not keeping promises. It’s like when a friend tells you something important, and you tell someone else instead of keeping it pri...
examples: If you tell a secret that your friend shared with you, it can really betray their trust.
In the game, if you choose to team up with the other players, you might betray your friends who are on your side.
When someone tells the teacher about a classmate's mistake, it can feel like they betray the friendship they have.
If you promise to keep a surprise party secret and then spill the beans, you might betray your friend’s excitement.
In the story, the knight had to decide whether to betray his kingdom or stay loyal to the king he served.

meanings: A beverage is any drink that you can enjoy, like water, juice, or milk. It's something you sip when you're thirsty!
examples: After soccer practice, my coach always gives us a refreshing beverage to help us cool down.
At the picnic, we brought sandwiches and a tasty beverage to share with everyone.
During the science fair, we learned that water is the most important beverage for our bodies.
When I read my favorite book, I like to sip on a warm beverage to make it even more enjoyable.
For my birthday party, I served a colorful beverage made with fruit juice and sparkling water.

meanings: Bland means food that doesn't have much taste or flavor, like plain rice or unseasoned chicken. It can also mean something that is not exciting or interesting.
examples: The soup tasted really bland, so I added some salt and pepper to make it more delicious.
I found a bland book at the library that didn’t have any exciting adventures or interesting characters.
During lunch, my sandwich was so bland that I wished I had packed some spicy chips to eat with it.
The movie was really bland because there were no funny moments or cool action scenes to enjoy.
My mom said that the plain rice was too bland, so she added some vegetables and sauce to make it tastier.

meanings: A blizzard is a very strong snowstorm with lots of wind that makes it hard to see and stay warm. It's when the snow falls so heavily that you might want to stay inside and drink hot chocolate!
examples: The blizzard made it hard to see outside, so we stayed inside and played board games all day.
During the blizzard, we built a giant snowman in the front yard while the wind howled around us.
School was canceled because of the blizzard, and I was excited to have an extra day to read my favorite book.
My dad told me stories about how people used to get stuck in their homes during a blizzard a long time ago.
After the blizzard passed, we went outside to explore the beautiful, white world that was left behind.

meanings: Boisterous means being very loud and full of energy, like when kids are playing and having a lot of fun together.
examples: The boisterous kids at the birthday party were laughing and playing games with excitement.
During recess, our boisterous group of friends ran around the playground, making everyone smile.
The boisterous crowd cheered loudly when the home team scored a goal in the big game.
At the zoo, the boisterous monkeys made funny sounds that made all the visitors laugh.
We enjoyed a boisterous afternoon of singing and dancing at the school talent show.

meanings: Being held in a way that makes you unable to move freely, like being tied up or trapped.
examples: The story we read in class showed how the hero escaped from bondage and found freedom in a magical land.
In history, we learned about people who were held in bondage and how they fought for their rights and freedom.
When the puppet show began, we noticed that the puppets were tied in bondage until the show started and they could dance.
In our science project, we discovered how plants can be in bondage if they don't get enough sunlight or water to grow properly.
The video game had a level where the character needed to break free from bondage to save the princess and complete the quest.

meanings: A brace is a special support that helps hold something steady, like when you wear a brace on your teeth to make them straight or a brace on your leg to help it heal.
examples: My brother wore a brace on his knee after he hurt it playing soccer last week.
The dentist gave me a special brace to help straighten my teeth for a beautiful smile.
When building the treehouse, we used a strong brace to hold the walls together so it would be safe.
In science class, we learned how a brace can help support a broken bone while it heals.
My friend showed me how to use a brace to hold her drawing pad steady while she painted.

meanings: Brilliant" means something that is very bright, like a shining star, or it can describe a person who is very smart and has great ideas.
examples: The scientist had a brilliant idea for a new invention that could help clean the ocean.
During art class, Mia created a brilliant painting that amazed everyone in the school.
Our soccer team played brilliantly in the tournament and won first place!
The brilliant sunshine made the flowers in the garden look even more colorful and beautiful.
In the book, the brilliant detective solved the mystery before anyone else could figure it out.

meanings: Brittle means something that can break easily, like a dry leaf or a piece of glass. It’s not strong or flexible, so if you press or hit it, it might snap or shatter.
examples: The brittle leaves crunched under our feet as we walked through the autumn forest.
When I tried to bend the brittle stick, it snapped in half with a loud crack.
The glass ornament was beautiful but very brittle, so we had to be careful not to drop it.
In science class, we learned that some materials are brittle and can break easily when too much pressure is applied.
My mom warned me that the brittle cookies would crumble if I touched them too hard.

meanings: To budge means to move a little bit or to change position, like when you try to push a heavy toy and it shifts just a tiny bit.
examples: I tried to budge the heavy rock, but it wouldn’t move no matter how hard I pushed.
When I asked my little brother to budge over on the couch, he just laughed and stayed put.
The teacher told us to budge our desks closer together for the group project we were working on.
During the soccer game, I had to budge my position to make space for my teammate to score a goal.
The puppy wouldn’t budge from his favorite sunny spot on the floor, even when it was time for a walk.

meanings: To mess up a task because you didn't do it carefully, which can lead to mistakes or problems.
examples: When I tried to bake cookies by myself, I really bungled the recipe and ended up with a gooey mess.
During our science project, we bungled the experiment by mixing the wrong ingredients, and it didn’t work at all.
In soccer practice, I bungled my kick and accidentally sent the ball flying into the neighbor's yard.
While building my model rocket, I bungled the assembly and had to start over because it wouldn’t stand up straight.
When we played the board game, I bungled my turn and forgot to follow the rules, which confused everyone.

meanings: A burden is something heavy or hard to carry, like a big backpack full of books, or a responsibility that feels tough to handle, like taking care of a pet.
examples: Helping my little brother with his homework can sometimes feel like a burden because he needs a lot of my attention.
During the school project, I felt the burden of making sure everyone worked together and did their part.
When my dad got sick, I took on the burden of helping out more around the house.
Carrying the heavy backpack to school every day became a burden, so I decided to leave some books at home.
In the story, the hero faced a great burden when he had to save his village from danger all by himself.

meanings: Burly" means big and strong, like a superhero or a big bear. It describes someone who has a strong and muscular body.
examples: The burly man lifted the heavy boxes with ease, showing everyone how strong he was.
In the story, the burly bear protected her cubs from danger in the deep, dark forest.
During gym class, our burly coach taught us how to lift weights safely and correctly.
The burly character in the movie became a hero by saving the day with his incredible strength.
At the zoo, we saw a burly gorilla that was much bigger than all the other animals.

meanings: The word "carcass" means the body of an animal that has died, especially one that is used for food.
examples: When we went to the nature reserve, we saw the carcass of a deer that had been eaten by scavengers.
In science class, we learned about how the carcass of an animal can help feed other creatures in the ecosystem.
The zookeeper explained that the carcass of a dead animal is often used to teach students about wildlife and biology.
During our camping trip, we found the carcass of a fish near the river, which showed us how nature recycles life.
In the book we read, a detective discovered a carcass in the woods, which helped him solve the mystery of the missing animals.

meanings: Cargo is the goods or items that are loaded onto a truck, ship, or airplane to be taken to another place. It's like the packages and products you see being delivered to stores or homes.
examples: The big ship sailed into the harbor, carrying cargo filled with toys for children all around the world.
During our field trip, we learned how trucks transport cargo like food and clothes to different stores.
In the video game, players can earn points by successfully delivering cargo to various cities on a map.
The airplane flew high in the sky, bringing cargo that included books and school supplies for kids in another country.
When the train arrived at the station, it was loaded with cargo that included all sorts of delicious snacks for the fair.

meanings: A carnivore is an animal that mainly eats meat, like lions and wolves. They hunt other animals to find their food.
examples: A lion is a carnivore because it hunts and eats other animals like zebras and antelopes.
In our science class, we learned that a shark is a carnivore that swims in the ocean looking for fish.
When we visited the zoo, we saw a big bear, which is sometimes a carnivore depending on what it eats.
In the animal kingdom, a carnivore like the wolf works together with its pack to catch prey for food.
My favorite dinosaur is the T-rex because it was a fierce carnivore that hunted smaller dinosaurs.

meanings: A cask is a big wooden barrel used to hold liquids like wine or beer. It's like a giant container that keeps drinks safe and fresh.
examples: The old pirate movie showed a cask filled with treasure, making everyone excited to see what was inside.
During our science project, we learned that a cask can hold liquids and is often made of wood.
At the museum, we saw a huge cask used to store wine, and it was almost as tall as me!
In the story, the brave explorer found a cask buried in the sand, full of delicious fruit juice.
My dad told me that in ancient times, people used casks to keep their drinks safe and fresh for a long time.

meanings: A catapult is a big machine that throws things far away by using a strong arm or rope. It was often used in battles a long time ago to launch rocks or other objects at enemies.
examples: In science class, we learned how to build a simple catapult using popsicle sticks and rubber bands.
During the historical reenactment, the students operated a giant catapult that launched soft projectiles into the field.
In the backyard, we used a small catapult to see how far we could launch marshmallows.
My favorite part of the video game was using a catapult to knock down the enemy's castle walls.
The ancient warriors used a catapult to fling heavy stones at their enemies during battles long ago.

meanings: To celebrate means to have fun and enjoy a special day or event, like a birthday party or a holiday, often with friends and family.
examples: We celebrate our birthdays by having parties, eating cake, and playing games with our friends and family.
In school, we celebrate Earth Day by planting trees and cleaning up our playground to help the environment.
Every year, we celebrate the Fourth of July by watching fireworks and having a picnic with our neighbors.
When our team wins a game, we celebrate by cheering, high-fiving each other, and enjoying some ice cream together.
During the holidays, our family likes to celebrate by decorating the house and cooking special meals that everyone loves.

meanings: A challenge is something that is hard to do and makes you think or work harder, like a tough puzzle or a difficult game level. It can be a chance to learn and get better at something!
examples: Learning to ride a bike was a big challenge for me, but I finally did it after practicing every day.
In science class, we had a challenge to build the tallest tower using only paper and tape.
My soccer team faced a tough challenge when we played against the best team in our league last Saturday.
Reading a thick book can be a challenge, but it feels amazing to finish it and share my thoughts with friends.
During our nature hike, we encountered the challenge of climbing a steep hill, but we all helped each other succeed.

meanings: A character is a person or an animal in a story, movie, or play that has their own feelings and actions, like Harry Potter or Simba from The Lion King.
examples: The main character in the book I read is a brave girl who goes on an adventure to save her village.
In our school play, I get to play the character of a funny robot who loves to dance.
My favorite video game has a character who can fly and help others complete challenges.
The character traits of kindness and honesty are important for making good friends.
In history class, we learned about a character named Martin Luther King Jr. who fought for equality.

meanings: A cluster is a group of things or people that are gathered closely together, like a bunch of grapes or a group of friends standing together.
examples: A cluster of stars twinkled brightly in the night sky, making it easy to spot the Big Dipper.
In science class, we learned that a cluster of cells can work together to keep our bodies healthy.
At the park, we saw a cluster of kids playing soccer and having a fantastic time.
My teacher showed us a cluster of colorful flowers in the garden and explained how they help bees.
During the school project, we formed a cluster of ideas to create a great presentation about our favorite animals.

meanings: A colony is a place where a group of people or animals live together in a new area, usually controlled by a larger country or group that helps them.
examples: The ant colony worked together to build their home and gather food for the entire group.
In history class, we learned about how the first American colony was started by brave settlers.
When we visited the zoo, we saw a penguin colony swimming together in their icy habitat.
My science project is about how bees form a colony to take care of their queen and larvae.
In the video game, players can create their own colony and help it grow by building houses and farms.

meanings: To combine means to take two or more things and mix them together to make something new, like when you mix different colors of paint to create a new color.
examples: In art class, we can combine different colors of paint to create new shades for our paintings.
When making a fruit salad, you should combine apples, bananas, and berries to make it delicious and healthy.
During science class, we learned how to combine vinegar and baking soda to make a fizzy volcano.
For our school project, we decided to combine our ideas about recycling to create a fun presentation.
In soccer, it's important to combine teamwork and strategy to play well and win the game.

meanings: A companion is a friend or pet that is with you, sharing fun times and making you feel happy and not alone.
examples: My dog is my best companion because he always plays with me and keeps me company when I’m feeling lonely.
During our camping trip, my sister was my perfect companion as we explored the forest and discovered new animal tracks together.
In the book I read, a brave knight had a loyal companion who helped him on every adventure he faced.
At school, having a study companion makes learning new things easier and more fun because we can help each other.
When I go on hikes, my favorite companion is my friend, who shares interesting facts about the plants and animals we see along the way.

meanings: Compassion is when you feel really sorry for someone who is hurting or having a hard time, and you want to help them feel better.
examples: When my friend fell off his bike, I felt compassion for him and helped him get back up.
In the story, the hero showed compassion by helping the lost puppy find its way home.
During our community service project, we learned that showing compassion can really make a difference for those in need.
I felt compassion for my classmate when I saw him sitting alone at lunch, so I invited him to join us.
When my sister was sad about her broken toy, I showed her compassion by giving her a hug and cheering her up.

meanings: When two things are compatible, it means they can work well together and don’t cause problems. For example, a puzzle piece is compatible with another piece if it fits together nicely.
examples: My new video game is compatible with my friend's console, so we can play together online.
In science class, we learned that some plants are compatible and grow well together in the same garden.
My best friend and I are compatible because we both love the same kinds of books and movies.
The two puzzle pieces were compatible and fit together perfectly to complete the picture.
When we work on group projects, it's important that our ideas are compatible so everyone can agree.

meanings: To make up for something you lost or did wrong by giving something back or doing something nice.
examples: When I accidentally spilled juice on my homework, I worked extra hard to compensate by rewriting it carefully.
After losing the soccer game, our coach organized a fun practice to compensate for our disappointment and help us improve.
If you forget to bring a snack for lunch, you can compensate by sharing some of your fruit with a friend.
My brother broke my toy, but he promised to compensate by saving his allowance to buy me a new one.
To compensate for missing the school field trip, I wrote a report about what I learned from my friends who went.

meanings: To do what you are asked or to follow the rules. For example, if your teacher asks you to raise your hand before speaking, you comply by raising your hand.
examples: To win the game, all players must comply with the rules set by the referee.
The teacher asked us to comply with her instructions for the science project to ensure we all did our best.
When we go on a field trip, we must comply with safety guidelines to keep everyone safe.
My parents expect me to comply with their bedtime rules so I can get enough sleep for school.
During the group project, we agreed to comply with each other's ideas to make our presentation better.

meanings: To comprehend means to understand something really well, like when you read a story and know what is happening and why the characters feel a certain way.
examples: In science class, we learned about the water cycle, and I was excited to comprehend how rain is formed.
When I read my favorite book, I had to stop and think for a moment to fully comprehend the story.
During math lessons, I often ask my teacher questions to help me comprehend the tricky problems we are solving.
After watching the documentary about animals, I could better comprehend the importance of protecting their habitats.
My dad explained the rules of the game, and I was finally able to comprehend how to play it with my friends.

meanings: To keep something out of sight so that others cannot see it. For example, you might conceal a surprise gift by hiding it in a closet.
examples: I wanted to conceal my surprise party plans from my best friend so it would be a fun surprise.
The magician knew how to conceal the rabbit in his hat before revealing it to the amazed audience.
When I found a secret hiding spot in the tree, I decided to conceal my favorite book there.
To win the game, I had to conceal my strategy from my opponents until the right moment.
The detective tried to conceal the clues so that only he could figure out the mystery.

meanings: A concept is an idea that helps us understand something better, like thinking about what friendship means or what makes a good team.
examples: In science class, we learned the concept of gravity, which explains why things fall to the ground.
The concept of teamwork is important in sports because working together helps us win games.
In our history lesson, we discussed the concept of democracy and how it allows people to vote.
The concept of friendship means being kind and supportive to each other, just like we are in our group.
When reading a story, understanding the main concept helps us remember what the book is about.

meanings: Feeling sure about yourself and what you can do, like when you believe you can ride a bike or solve a tricky math problem.
examples: I felt confident when I raised my hand in class to answer the teacher’s question about our science project.
Before the big soccer game, I practiced a lot and became confident in my ability to score a goal.
When I performed my dance in front of the school, I was confident and smiled at the audience.
After studying hard for the spelling test, I was confident that I would do well and get a good grade.
My mom said I should be confident in my art skills because my painting turned out really nice.

meanings: To conquer means to win a difficult battle or to overcome a challenge. It's like when you practice hard and finally beat a tough level in a video game or finish a big project at school.
examples: I worked hard to conquer my fear of speaking in front of the class during the presentation.
In the video game, you must conquer each level to reach the final boss and win the game.
The brave knight set out on a quest to conquer the dragon and save the village from danger.
With practice and determination, I was able to conquer the math problems that once seemed impossible.
After many attempts, I finally conquered the tall climbing wall at the playground, and it felt amazing!

meanings: To consist means to be made of different parts or things. For example, a sandwich consists of bread, meat, and cheese.
examples: A pizza can consist of many toppings like cheese, pepperoni, mushrooms, and peppers, making it delicious and fun to share.
The science project will consist of several parts, including a poster, a model, and a presentation to explain our findings.
My favorite sandwich consists of peanut butter, jelly, and banana, which makes it sweet and tasty for lunch.
The book I’m reading consists of three exciting stories about friendship, adventure, and bravery that keep me turning the pages.
Our team will consist of five players, and we need to practice together to win the next soccer game.

meanings: To consume means to eat or drink something. It also means to use up things, like when you use all the juice in a bottle.
examples: When we eat lunch at school, we consume a lot of energy to help us learn and play.
Plants consume sunlight, water, and nutrients from the soil to grow tall and strong.
My family tries to consume less plastic by using reusable bags when we go shopping.
In science class, we learned that animals consume food to get the energy they need to move and grow.
When I read a book, I consume the story and imagine all the adventures in my mind.

meanings: Contact means to talk or send a message to someone, like when you call a friend or write a note to your teacher.
examples: I will contact my teacher if I have questions about the homework assignment.
During our science project, we need to contact a local expert to learn more about the topic.
I made sure to contact my grandparents regularly so they know how I'm doing at school.
When we planned the soccer tournament, we had to contact all the teams to sign up.
If you see a lost pet, you should contact the animal shelter to help find its owner.

meanings: To get better and feel strong again after being sick or hurt.
examples: After the surgery, my grandma needed some time to convalesce before she could bake her famous cookies again.
When I caught a cold, I stayed home from school to rest and convalesce so I could feel better quickly.
The doctor said I should take it easy and convalesce for a week after my sprained ankle to heal properly.
My friend went to the hospital, but now he is back home to convalesce and play video games with me again.
During the summer, I plan to convalesce at the beach, resting and enjoying the sunshine after my busy school year.

meanings: To convince someone means to make them believe something or agree to do something by explaining your ideas well. For example, if you want your friend to play a game with you, you might tell them why i...
examples: I tried to convince my mom to let me have a sleepover with my friends this weekend.
My teacher used a fun experiment to convince us that plants need sunlight to grow.
During the game, I needed to convince my teammates that my idea for a new strategy would work.
I wanted to convince my sister to read the book I loved because I knew she would enjoy it too.
At the science fair, I had to convince the judges that my project was the best one there.

meanings: A course is a path or direction that someone takes, like when you follow a road to get somewhere. It can also mean a group of lessons you take at school to learn something new.
examples: In gym class, we learned how to play soccer, and our coach explained the best course to score a goal.
The science teacher took us on a field trip to the nature reserve as part of our ecology course.
During the summer, I plan to take a cooking course to learn how to make my favorite meals.
As we hiked up the mountain, we followed the course marked by colorful signs along the trail.
In history class, we studied the course of events that led to the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

meanings: To crave something means to really, really want it, like when you can't stop thinking about your favorite food or toy.
examples: After a long day at school, I often crave a big bowl of ice cream to enjoy while I do my homework.
When I read exciting adventure books, I crave the thrill of exploring new worlds and meeting interesting characters.
During soccer practice, I crave the feeling of scoring a goal and celebrating with my teammates.
On hot summer days, I always crave a cold lemonade to help me cool down and feel refreshed.
After watching a fun movie, I sometimes crave popcorn, because it makes the experience even better!

meanings: A crevice is a small, narrow crack or space between two things, like the gap between rocks or the space in a broken wall.
examples: I found a tiny spider hiding in the crevice of the old tree trunk during our nature walk.
While building my sandcastle at the beach, I noticed a small crevice where the water collected.
The teacher showed us a rock with a crevice, explaining how it was formed over many years.
As we explored the cave, we saw bats resting in the dark crevice above our heads.
During our science project, we learned that plants can grow in the crevice of rocks if they have enough sunlight.

meanings: To prepare the soil and take care of plants so they can grow strong and healthy.
examples: To cultivate a garden, we need to prepare the soil and plant seeds so they can grow big and strong.
In science class, we learned how farmers cultivate crops by using tools to help the plants grow better.
My mom and I decided to cultivate some flowers in our backyard to make it look colorful and inviting.
We should cultivate our friendships by being kind and helpful to each other every day at school.
To cultivate a good habit like reading, I try to spend at least twenty minutes with a book each night.

meanings: Something that is large or heavy, making it hard to move or use easily. For example, a big box or a heavy backpack can be cumbersome to carry around.
examples: Carrying the cumbersome backpack filled with books made it hard for me to walk quickly to class.
The old computer is so cumbersome that it takes up a lot of space on my desk and is hard to move.
When we went camping, we realized our tent was too cumbersome to set up by ourselves in the windy weather.
My little brother tried to ride his bicycle with the cumbersome training wheels, but he kept wobbling and falling over.
Building a large model rocket can be fun, but the cumbersome pieces make it tricky to put together without help.

meanings: A decade is a time period that lasts for ten years, like from 2010 to 2020. It’s a way to talk about how things change over a long time, like how music or fashion can be different from one decade to t...
examples: A decade is like ten birthdays, so we can celebrate how much we’ve grown over the years.
In the last decade, many new video games have been created that kids love to play.
My grandma told me that a decade ago, she used to ride her bike to school every day.
Scientists study changes in the environment over a decade to see how nature is affected.
It’s exciting to think how much technology will change in the next decade as we grow up!

meanings: To decline means to become smaller or weaker, like when a plant doesn't get enough water and starts to wilt. It can also mean to say no to something, like when you don't want a piece of cake.
examples: The number of butterflies in our garden seems to decline every year, so we decided to plant more flowers to help them.
When the weather gets colder, the amount of sunlight can decline, making it harder for plants to grow.
I had to decline the invitation to the birthday party because I had a soccer game on the same day.
If we don't recycle, the amount of trash in our landfills will continue to decline our planet's health.
My grades began to decline when I stopped studying regularly, so I made a plan to improve them.

meanings: To decrease means to get smaller or to have less of something. For example, if you eat fewer cookies, the number of cookies you have decreases.
examples: When the temperature starts to decrease in the fall, we know it's time to wear warmer clothes.
If we decrease the amount of sugar in our recipe, the cookies will be less sweet but still tasty.
During our science experiment, we watched how the water level would decrease as it evaporated in the sun.
If we practice our math problems every day, we can decrease the number of mistakes we make on tests.
When we turn off the lights when we leave a room, we can help decrease the amount of electricity we use.

meanings: To dedicate something means to use it for a special purpose or to promise to spend time and effort on something important, like practicing a sport or helping a friend.
examples: I want to dedicate my time to learning how to play the guitar this summer.
The teacher asked us to dedicate a few minutes each day to reading our favorite books.
My mom decided to dedicate her Saturday to helping me finish my science project.
We should dedicate part of our garden to growing flowers for the bees and butterflies.
During the game, I will dedicate all my energy to helping my team win the championship!

meanings: Something that is delicate is very light and can be easily broken or hurt, like a thin piece of glass or a flower petal. You need to be gentle and careful when you handle it.
examples: The delicate butterfly landed softly on the flower, its colorful wings fluttering gently in the breeze.
When we make a model volcano for science class, we have to be careful because the materials are delicate.
My grandma has a delicate glass ornament that she keeps on a high shelf to keep it safe from breaking.
While hiking, we spotted delicate wildflowers growing in the rocky soil, showing us how nature can thrive in tough places.
In art class, we learned to paint on delicate paper that could tear easily if we pressed too hard with the brush.

meanings: To say publicly that something is bad or wrong; to tell others that you don’t agree with it.
examples: The teacher decided to denounce bullying in the classroom, explaining why it is wrong and how it hurts others.
During the school assembly, the principal will denounce cheating in tests to encourage everyone to be honest and fair.
In the story we read, the hero chose to denounce the evil plans of the villain to protect the village.
My dad will denounce littering in our park during the community clean-up day to help keep nature beautiful.
When my friend saw someone being unkind, she felt it was important to denounce that behavior and stand up for what is right.

meanings: When something is dense, it means it is packed very closely together, like a thick forest where it's hard to see through the trees.
examples: The forest was so dense that we could hardly see the sky through the thick trees and leaves.
In science class, we learned that a dense fog can make it hard to see when driving.
The book was dense with information, so it took me a while to understand all the details.
When we made slime, the mixture became dense and sticky, making it fun to play with.
My backpack felt dense with all the heavy books I had to carry home from school.

meanings: To depart means to leave a place, like when your family drives away from home for a trip or when a bus pulls away from a bus stop.
examples: The train will depart from the station at 3 PM, so we need to get there on time.
When the school bell rings, all the students will depart for home together.
After the camping trip, we will depart from the forest and head back to the city.
Our class will depart for the museum at 10 AM to learn about dinosaurs and history.
The birds will depart for warmer places as winter approaches, leaving the trees quiet and bare.

meanings: To put money into a bank account or to leave something in a certain place for safekeeping.
examples: I went to the bank with my dad to deposit my birthday money into my savings account.
After we finished the science project, I had to deposit the materials back in the classroom.
My mom told me to deposit my allowance into my piggy bank every week so I can save for a new game.
When I finished reading the library book, I had to deposit it in the return bin before the due date.
We decided to deposit all the coins we found on the playground into a jar for our school charity.

meanings: Despair is a feeling when you think things will never get better, and you feel very sad and lost. It's like being in a dark room with no light, where you can't see a way out.
examples: When I lost the final soccer game, I felt a wave of despair because I had hoped to win the trophy.
After studying all week for the test, I was in despair when I realized I still didn’t understand the material.
Seeing my plant droop after forgetting to water it made me feel a little despair about my gardening skills.
My friend felt despair when he couldn't find his favorite book in the library, even though he searched everywhere.
After our team lost the championship, some players sat in despair, wondering if they would ever win a game.

meanings: Feeling very worried or helpless because things are really bad and seem impossible to fix.
examples: When the basketball game was tied and there were only a few seconds left, our team felt desperate to score a point.
She was desperate to find her lost dog, so she called all her friends to help search the neighborhood.
During the science fair, I felt desperate when my project fell apart just minutes before the judges arrived.
He was desperate for a good grade on his test, so he studied all night long to prepare.
In the middle of the race, I felt desperate because I was so tired and wanted to give up, but I kept going.

meanings: A destination is the place where you are going, like your friend's house or a fun park. It’s the spot you want to reach when you travel.
examples: Our class trip's destination is the science museum, where we will learn about dinosaurs and space.
For summer vacation, our family's destination is the beach, where we will build sandcastles and swim in the ocean.
When we play the treasure hunt game, the final destination is under the big oak tree in the park.
The destination of our hiking adventure is the top of the mountain, where we can see the beautiful view.
I can't wait to reach our destination, which is the library, so I can borrow new books to read.

meanings: To deteriorate means to get worse over time, like when a toy breaks or food spoils and isn't as good as it used to be.
examples: If we don’t take care of our school supplies, they will deteriorate and become unusable over time.
The old tree in our backyard started to deteriorate after the storm, losing many of its leaves and branches.
If you leave your sandwich out too long, it will deteriorate and won't be safe to eat.
My favorite book began to deteriorate because I read it so many times that the pages started to tear.
The playground equipment can deteriorate if it is not regularly checked and repaired by the school.

meanings: To dictate means to read or say something out loud so that someone else can write it down, like when a teacher tells you what to write in your notebook.
examples: The teacher will dictate the spelling words for us to write in our notebooks during class.
My dad likes to dictate his stories into a recorder so he can write them down later.
In the game, the leader will dictate the rules so everyone knows how to play properly.
During our science project, we will dictate our ideas to each other to make sure everyone understands.
When my mom cooks, she sometimes dictates the recipe steps for me to write down in my cookbook.

meanings: A disaster is a bad event like a big storm or earthquake that causes a lot of damage and makes people very unhappy.
examples: When the big storm hit our town, it caused a disaster that left many homes damaged and families in need of help.
In science class, we learned that a volcanic eruption can be a disaster for the animals and plants living nearby.
When our group project fell apart because no one did their part, it felt like a disaster for our grade.
The movie we watched had a story about a disaster that struck a small village and how the people worked together to rebuild.
During the soccer game, when it started pouring rain, the match turned into a disaster, and we all got soaked!

meanings: To distract means to make someone stop thinking about what they were doing or paying attention to. For example, if you're trying to read and someone is making noise, they can distract you.
examples: It’s hard to concentrate on my homework when my little brother tries to distract me with his silly jokes.
During the movie, my phone rang, and it really distracted me from the exciting parts of the story.
When I’m practicing my soccer skills, my friends sometimes distract me by cheering loudly from the sidelines.
The colorful butterflies in the garden can easily distract me when I’m trying to read my book outside.
In science class, we learned that loud noises can distract animals, making it hard for them to find food.

meanings: Distress is when you feel very worried, sad, or hurt, like when you lose a favorite toy or have a big problem that makes you feel upset.
examples: When the dog got lost in the park, it caused a lot of distress for its owner.
In the story, the hero felt great distress when he couldn't find his missing friend.
Seeing her friend cry made Mia feel distress because she wanted to help her feel better.
The loud thunderstorm at night filled me with distress as I worried about my family’s safety.
During the test, I felt some distress because I wasn’t sure if I studied enough.

meanings: To dominate means to be the strongest or most powerful in a situation, like when a player on a sports team leads everyone to win the game.
examples: In basketball, the tallest players often dominate the game by scoring the most points and blocking shots.
During our class debate, Sarah was able to dominate the discussion with her strong arguments and good points.
In video games, some characters can dominate their opponents by using special skills and strategies to win.
When the sun shines bright, it can dominate the sky, making everything look warm and cheerful.
In our science project, we learned that certain animals dominate their habitats, like lions in the savanna or sharks in the ocean.

meanings: To donate means to give things like toys, clothes, or money to help people who need them. It's a kind way to share what you have and make someone else's life better.
examples: My class decided to donate old books to the library so more kids could enjoy reading.
During the holiday season, our family likes to donate clothes and toys to help those in need.
At the school fundraiser, we can donate money to support local animal shelters and help them care for pets.
For my birthday, I asked my friends to donate money to a charity instead of giving me gifts.
Every year, my soccer team donates a portion of our game fees to support children's sports programs.

meanings: Dormant means something that is resting and not doing anything right now, like a seed that is waiting to grow when the weather gets warm.
examples: The seeds in the garden are dormant during the winter, waiting for the warm spring sun to help them grow.
When a volcano is dormant, it means it hasn’t erupted for a long time but could become active again someday.
The bear hibernates in its den, remaining dormant until the weather gets warmer and food becomes easier to find.
In science class, we learned that some plants become dormant in dry seasons to survive without water.
After a long soccer season, my muscles felt dormant, and I needed to stretch and move to feel active again.

meanings: A drought is a time when there is very little or no rain for a long time, causing plants and animals to have less water to drink and grow.
examples: This summer, our town experienced a drought, so we had to be careful about how much water we used in our gardens.
During the drought, the pond near my house dried up, and we could see the muddy bottom where fish once swam.
In science class, we learned that a drought can make it hard for farmers to grow crops and feed their animals.
I read a book about a desert where a long drought made it difficult for plants and animals to survive.
When there is a drought, people often need to find new ways to save water for drinking and washing.

meanings: The duration is how long something takes, like the time you spend playing a game or watching a movie.
examples: The duration of our school day is six hours, but it feels shorter when we’re having fun in class.
In science class, we learned that the duration of a butterfly’s life can be as short as a few weeks.
During our soccer game, the duration of each half is 30 minutes, and we try our best to score goals.
The duration of the movie we watched last night was two hours, and I really enjoyed every minute of it.
When baking cookies, the duration for them to bake is about 15 minutes, which seems like forever when you’re waiting!

meanings: Safe to eat; if something is edible, it means you can eat it without getting sick.
examples: The teacher explained that not all plants are edible, so we should be careful when picking berries in the wild.
During our science project, we learned that chocolate is made from edible cacao beans found in tropical regions.
At lunch, I discovered that the apple slices were much more delicious and edible than the wilted lettuce.
My mom taught me how to tell which mushrooms are edible and which ones we should avoid in the forest.
When we went camping, we cooked hot dogs over the fire because they are easy to prepare and definitely edible.

meanings: Having a beautiful and simple style that looks really nice, like a fancy dress or a graceful dance.
examples: The elegant dress my sister wore to the party sparkled under the lights and made her look like a princess.
During our science project, we learned that the elegant movements of a butterfly help it fly gracefully from flower to flower.
The elegant way the ballerina danced across the stage made everyone in the audience clap and cheer.
My mom set the table for dinner with elegant plates and shiny silverware that made the meal feel special.
In the museum, we saw an elegant painting of a landscape that made us feel like we were in a beautiful dream.

meanings: To employ someone means to give them a job or work to do, like when a store hires a person to help customers.
examples: My dad decided to employ a gardener to help take care of our big backyard.
In art class, our teacher will employ different materials like paint and clay for our projects.
The school will employ a new coach to help us learn more about soccer this year.
For our science project, we can employ a variety of experiments to learn about plants and how they grow.
During the summer camp, the counselors will employ fun games to keep us active and entertained.

meanings: To meet or find someone or something by surprise, like when you bump into a friend at the park when you weren't expecting to see them.
examples: During our nature walk, we might encounter a deer hiding among the trees if we are very quiet.
In the library, I hope to encounter a book about space that will take me on an exciting adventure.
While playing soccer, I had an unexpected encounter with a dog that ran onto the field to join the game.
When I went to the museum, I encountered a giant dinosaur skeleton that amazed me with its size.
At the science fair, I encountered a project about volcanoes that inspired me to learn more about how they work.

meanings: Equivalent means that two things are the same in some way, like having the same value or purpose. For example, if you have one dollar and a friend has four quarters, those are equivalent because they...
examples: In math class, we learned that one quarter is equivalent to 25 cents.
The two paintings looked different, but their colors made them equivalent in beauty.
When you add two plus two, the answer is equivalent to four, no matter how you say it.
My teacher said that reading for 20 minutes is equivalent to finishing one chapter of a book.
In soccer, scoring a goal is equivalent to getting a point for your team.

meanings: To slowly wear away or break down something over time, like how rain or wind can make rocks smaller or change the shape of a mountain.
examples: Over time, the strong waves can erode the sandy beach, making it smaller and smaller each year.
When it rains heavily, the water can erode the soil on the hillside, causing small landslides.
The old castle's walls began to erode because of the wind and rain over many centuries.
In science class, we learned how rivers can erode rocks and create beautiful canyons over thousands of years.
If we don’t take care of our playground, the swings and slides may erode and become unsafe to use.

meanings: To suddenly burst out with a lot of force, like when a volcano blows out lava or when a big argument happens.
examples: When the volcano started to erupt, everyone in the town had to evacuate to stay safe.
During the science fair, my volcano project erupted with colorful foam, surprising all the judges.
In the movie, the dragon would erupt with fire whenever it got angry, making everyone run away.
During our art class, the kids erupted with excitement when they saw the new paint colors.
At recess, the soccer game erupted into cheers as our team scored the winning goal!

meanings: To increase in size, amount, or seriousness. For example, if a small argument between friends gets bigger and turns into a big fight, we say it has escalated.
examples: When the arguments between the two friends continued, their disagreement began to escalate, making everyone around them uncomfortable.
During the soccer game, the excitement started to escalate as both teams scored goals and the crowd cheered louder.
If we don’t fix the leaky faucet soon, the problem will escalate, and we might end up with a lot of water damage.
The science project was fun at first, but when we couldn't agree on ideas, the stress began to escalate.
As the storm approached, the winds began to escalate, and we knew it was time to head indoors for safety.

meanings: To start or create something in a way that makes it strong and lasting, like building a treehouse that you want to use for a long time.
examples: The teacher wanted to establish a reading club so that everyone could enjoy books together after school.
In science class, we worked hard to establish a garden where we could grow our own flowers and vegetables.
My dad helped me establish a chore chart to make sure I remember to clean my room and do my homework.
The coach wanted to establish a new team strategy to help us win the next soccer game.
We decided to establish a friendship by sharing our favorite games and playing together every weekend.

meanings: To avoid something by being smart or sneaky, like when you try to get away from a difficult question or a task you don’t want to do.
examples: The clever fox was able to evade the trap set by the hunter in the forest.
During hide and seek, I tried to evade my friends by hiding behind the big tree.
In the game, the hero must evade all the obstacles to reach the treasure at the end.
She used her quick thinking to evade answering the tricky question in class.
The rabbit can easily evade predators by hopping quickly through the tall grass.

meanings: Something that is evident is very clear and easy to see or understand, like when you can tell someone is happy just by looking at their smile.
examples: It was evident that Sarah studied hard for the math test because she answered all the questions quickly and correctly.
When the sun came out after the rain, it was evident that a beautiful rainbow would soon appear in the sky.
In our science project, it was evident that plants need sunlight to grow because the ones in the dark didn’t look healthy at all.
During the soccer game, it was evident that our team practiced a lot because we worked together so well on the field.
After we cleaned up the playground, it was evident that everyone enjoyed playing in the nice, tidy space.

meanings: To exasperate someone means to make them really frustrated or annoyed, like when you keep asking the same question and they just want you to stop.
examples: My little brother can exasperate me when he takes my toys without asking, especially when I'm trying to play with them.
During group projects, it can exasperate me when some classmates don't do their part and leave everything to the rest of us.
I get exasperated when my dog barks loudly every time the mailman comes, and I just want some peace and quiet.
When my mom asks me to clean my room for the fifth time, I start to feel exasperated because I think I already did it well.
It can exasperate me when my favorite video game has too many ads, making it hard to enjoy playing with my friends.

meanings: To dig a hole in the ground and take out the dirt or other materials, like when you use a shovel to make a sandbox.
examples: In science class, we learned how archaeologists excavate ancient sites to find buried treasures and fossils.
During the summer, my dad and I decided to excavate our backyard to make space for a new vegetable garden.
The kids in my neighborhood wanted to excavate a large hole for their fort, so they gathered shovels and started digging together.
When we went to the beach, we saw people excavate the sand to build a big sandcastle with towers and a moat.
In the museum, there was an exhibit showing how paleontologists excavate dinosaur bones from the ground to study them.

meanings: To use energy or effort to do something, like pushing a heavy box or studying for a test.
examples: To win the race, I had to exert all my strength and run as fast as I could.
During our science project, we had to exert a lot of effort to build the tallest tower possible.
When I play soccer, I exert energy to kick the ball and help my team score goals.
In art class, I had to exert my creativity to come up with a unique painting idea.
My mom always tells me to exert patience when I'm learning something new, like playing the piano.

meanings: To make something bigger or larger, like when you blow up a balloon and it expands.
examples: When we water the plants, they start to expand and grow bigger in the garden.
In science class, we learned how hot air can expand and fill a balloon until it pops.
The teacher said our ideas can expand when we work together on group projects in class.
As I read more books, my vocabulary began to expand, and I learned new words every day.
During the summer, my family plans to expand our garden by adding new flowers and vegetables.

meanings: To make someone leave a place, like when a teacher asks a student to go out of class for bad behavior.
examples: The teacher had to expel the student from class for not following the rules and being disruptive.
In the book, the wizard used a spell to expel the dark creatures from the enchanted forest.
During the soccer game, the referee decided to expel the player for cheating and not playing fair.
If you break the school’s important rules, you might be expelled and have to leave for a while.
The angry bee tried to expel the intruder from its hive by buzzing loudly and flying around.

meanings: An experiment is a test you do to learn something new or to see if an idea is right. It's like a science project where you try out different things and see what happens!
examples: In science class, we did an experiment to see how plants grow faster in sunlight compared to the dark.
My brother and I decided to conduct an experiment to find out which type of paper airplane flies the farthest.
During our school fair, we set up an experiment to show how vinegar and baking soda create a fizzy reaction.
For my art project, I wanted to experiment with mixing different colors of paint to create new shades.
We learned about gravity by doing an experiment where we dropped different objects to see which would fall faster.

meanings: To export means to send things like toys or food to another country so that people there can buy them.
examples: Our school is planning to export homemade cookies to a bakery in another country for a special event.
The science fair project showed how we can export fruits and vegetables to help other countries eat healthy foods.
In history class, we learned that long ago, people used to export silk from China to other parts of the world.
My dad's company will export toys to kids in other countries so they can enjoy playing with them too.
When we visited the museum, we saw a display about how countries export goods like coffee and chocolate.

meanings: Extinct means that a type of animal or plant no longer exists anywhere on Earth. For example, dinosaurs are extinct because there are no living dinosaurs today.
examples: Dinosaurs are extinct, which means they no longer roam the Earth like they did millions of years ago.
In science class, we learned that the woolly mammoth is an extinct animal that lived during the Ice Age.
The dodo bird is a famous example of an extinct species because it disappeared due to hunting and habitat loss.
It's important to protect endangered animals so they don’t become extinct like some species in the past.
When we read about extinct creatures in our history book, I was amazed at how different the world was back then.

meanings: To take something out of a bigger group or container, like when you extract juice from a fruit by squeezing it.
examples: To make juice, we need to extract the water from the fruits by squeezing them really hard.
In science class, we learned how to extract DNA from a banana using simple kitchen ingredients.
The doctor used a special tool to extract the cavity from my tooth so it wouldn’t hurt anymore.
When we made cookies, we had to extract the chocolate chips from the bag before adding them to the mix.
During our history project, we had to extract important facts from books and write them down in our own words.

meanings: To feel very happy and excited because something good has happened, like winning a game or doing well on a test.
examples: After winning the soccer game, the team began to exult, cheering and hugging each other in celebration.
When she received an A on her math test, Maria couldn't help but exult, jumping up and down with joy.
The students exulted when they heard that their class trip to the zoo was finally approved by the principal.
As the last puzzle piece clicked into place, the kids exulted, thrilled that they had completed the challenging picture together.
When the science fair project won first place, Jake and his partner exulted, feeling proud of their hard work and creativity.

meanings: Famine is a time when there isn't enough food for everyone, causing many people to feel very hungry and not have enough to eat.
examples: In history class, we learned about a famine that affected many people because there wasn't enough food to eat.
The storybook told how a brave hero helped his village survive during a terrible famine by finding hidden food supplies.
During the science project, we discussed how droughts can lead to famine when crops don't get enough water to grow.
My teacher explained that famine can happen after natural disasters, making it hard for people to find food for a long time.
In our geography lesson, we studied countries that have faced famine and talked about ways we can help those in need.

meanings: To fascinate means to grab someone's attention so much that they can't stop looking or thinking about it. It's like when you see a cool magic trick and you just want to watch it over and over again!
examples: The way butterflies change from caterpillars to beautiful insects fascinates many kids who love nature and science.
My science teacher showed us a video about space that fascinated everyone in the classroom.
Reading about ancient Egypt and how they built pyramids fascinates me because I enjoy learning about history.
The stories in my favorite book series fascinate me so much that I can’t put the books down.
When we visited the zoo, the way the monkeys played with each other fascinated all the children watching.

meanings: Feeble means very weak or not strong enough to do something. For example, if someone is feeling sick, they might feel too feeble to play outside.
examples: The feeble plant struggled to grow because it didn’t get enough sunlight or water.
During the soccer game, my feeble kick barely made the ball move forward.
The old bridge looked feeble, and I was a little scared to cross it.
After being sick for a week, I felt feeble and needed to rest before going back to school.
The feeble sound of the bell made it hard for the students to hear when class was over.

meanings: Very angry and ready to fight; like a wild animal that is scary and dangerous.
examples: The ferocious dog barked loudly, scaring all the kids playing outside.
In the jungle book, the ferocious tiger chased after the other animals to show its strength.
During the soccer match, the ferocious players fought hard to win the championship trophy.
The ferocious storm knocked down branches and made the wind howl through the trees.
In the video game, the ferocious dragon tried to protect its treasure from the brave hero.

meanings: Able to grow lots of plants or crops because the soil has plenty of good stuff in it. It means the ground is healthy and can help things grow well.
examples: The farmer was happy because the fertile soil helped him grow lots of delicious vegetables in his garden.
In science class, we learned that fertile land is important for growing crops that feed people all over the world.
The river made the valley fertile, allowing many plants and flowers to bloom beautifully in the spring.
After planting seeds in the fertile ground, we watched them grow into tall sunflowers that reached for the sky.
