Our teacher told us that ancient civilizations thrived in fertile areas where they could grow enough food to survive.

meanings: To move your arms or legs around quickly and wildly, like when you're trying to swim but you're not very good at it.
examples: During the soccer game, I saw my teammate flail his arms in excitement when he scored a goal.
When the wind picked up, the leaves began to flail around, dancing in the air like they were having a party.
As the puppy ran around the yard, it would flail its paws in the grass, trying to catch a butterfly.
When I got scared during the scary movie, I couldn't help but flail my hands in front of my face.
In art class, when I couldn’t find my paintbrush, I started to flail my arms, searching everywhere for it.

meanings: To run away quickly from a place or situation that feels unsafe or scary.
examples: When the storm came, we had to flee the playground and run inside the school for safety.
In the movie, the brave hero had to flee from the dragon to save the village.
During our nature hike, we saw a deer flee into the woods when it heard us coming.
If there’s a fire in the building, everyone must flee quickly and calmly to the nearest exit.
In our history lesson, we learned how people had to flee their homes during the war to find safety.

meanings: Easily broken or not strong; like a thin piece of paper that can tear easily.
examples: The flimsy paper airplane we made in class fell apart before it could fly very far.
During art class, I realized my flimsy glue stick couldn't hold the heavy decorations on my project.
I tried to carry the flimsy cardboard box, but it broke open and spilled my toys everywhere.
The flimsy bridge made of sticks wobbled whenever we walked across it during our nature hike.
When the wind blew, the flimsy kite we made in gym class got tangled in the trees.

meanings: Foolhardy means acting without thinking about how dangerous or silly it might be, like jumping off a high place just for fun.
examples: It was foolhardy for Jake to climb the tall tree without checking if it was safe first.
The team made a foolhardy decision to play soccer in the rain without wearing any proper gear.
Samantha thought it was foolhardy to ride her bike down the steep hill without a helmet on.
When the kids decided to explore the dark cave without a flashlight, it seemed like a foolhardy adventure.
Tom's foolhardy choice to skip studying for the test led to a surprise when he got a low grade.

meanings: Formal means doing something in a serious way that follows specific rules, like dressing nicely for a special event or using polite language when you meet someone important.
examples: At the school assembly, we wore formal clothes because it was an important event.
When writing a letter to the principal, it’s important to use a formal tone and proper greetings.
During the science fair, my project presentation was formal, and I made sure to speak clearly and confidently.
Our teacher explained that a formal dinner has rules about how to set the table and behave.
In history class, we learned about formal ceremonies that kings and queens held in ancient times.

meanings: Former means something that used to be true or used to exist, like a former teacher you had last year. It can also refer to the first of two things when you are talking about them.
examples: My former teacher taught us all about space and planets before she moved to a new school.
In history class, we learned about a former president who helped make our country better many years ago.
The former champion of the soccer league came to our school to give us a special lesson on teamwork.
I found an old toy in the attic that was a former favorite of mine when I was younger.
My former best friend and I used to build amazing forts out of blankets in the living room.

meanings: A fracture is when a bone breaks or cracks, which can happen if you fall or bump into something hard. It can hurt a lot, and doctors can help fix it so you can heal and feel better.
examples: When I fell off my bike, the doctor said I had a fracture in my wrist that needed a cast.
In science class, we learned that a fracture can happen to rocks when they are under too much pressure from the earth.
During our soccer game, my teammate got a fracture in his leg, so we all signed his cast to cheer him up.
The old tree in the park had a fracture in its trunk, which made it look very interesting and different from the other trees.
When I read my favorite adventure book, the hero faced a fracture in his arm but still managed to save the day!

meanings: Frigid means very, very cold, like when you go outside in winter and need to wear a heavy jacket. It can also describe someone who seems unfriendly or not warm-hearted.
examples: The frigid air made us wear our warmest jackets when we went outside to play in the snow.
After the frigid winter nights, the flowers began to bloom again when spring arrived.
The lake was so frigid that we decided not to go swimming during our summer camp.
During our science class, we learned that frigid temperatures can freeze water into ice very quickly.
When I opened the refrigerator, the frigid air made me shiver a little bit.

meanings: Frivolous means something that is not serious or important, like a silly joke or a fun game that doesn’t really matter.
examples: Some students think that using silly stickers on their homework is frivolous and distracts from the important work they need to finish.
During the meeting, the teacher reminded us that talking about our favorite video games was fun but a bit frivolous compared to discussing our project.
When planning the school party, we decided that spending too much money on frivolous decorations wasn't the best idea for our budget.
My little brother likes to make frivolous jokes during dinner, which makes everyone laugh, but sometimes we need to focus on our meal.
In the story, the character wasted his time on frivolous adventures instead of studying for the big test he had coming up.

meanings: To show that you are very angry, often by making a frowning face or acting upset.
examples: When I saw my brother break my favorite toy, I started to fume with anger.
After losing the soccer game, Jake began to fume and refused to talk to anyone.
The smoke from the campfire began to fume up into the night sky, making it hard to see the stars.
When the teacher said we had a surprise quiz, the whole class began to fume and groan loudly.
My mom could see me fume when I found out I had to do my chores before playing video games.

meanings: A gale is a very strong wind that can make it hard to walk outside and can even knock over trees or things that aren't heavy.
examples: The gale blew so hard that it knocked over the picnic table at the park during our field trip.
As we flew our kites, a sudden gale made them dance wildly in the sky before we could catch them.
The weather report warned us about a strong gale coming, so we decided to stay inside and play board games instead.
During the storm, the gale howled outside, making it sound like a giant was playing a spooky tune on the wind.
In our science class, we learned that a gale can make waves in the ocean rise high and crash on the shore.

meanings: Very, very big; something that is much larger than what we usually see, like a giant elephant or a huge building.
examples: The gigantic whale swam gracefully through the ocean, making it one of the biggest animals in the world.
When we went to the fair, I saw a gigantic Ferris wheel that looked like it touched the clouds.
In science class, we learned about dinosaurs, and the T-Rex was a gigantic creature that roamed the Earth millions of years ago.
My dad surprised me with a gigantic pizza for my birthday, and we had to share it with all my friends.
The gigantic redwood trees in the national park were so tall that they seemed to reach the sky!

meanings: To gorge means to eat a lot of food very quickly, like when you really enjoy a big feast and can't help but keep eating.
examples: After the big soccer game, we all gorged on pizza and soda to celebrate our victory.
During the camping trip, we gorged on marshmallows and chocolate while making s'mores by the fire.
I couldn't help but gorge on the delicious cookies my mom baked for the bake sale at school.
At the birthday party, everyone gorged on cake and ice cream until there was hardly any left.
When I read about the animals in the jungle, I learned that some gorged on fruits to stay healthy.

meanings: Grim means looking very serious or sad, like when someone is worried or has bad news. It can feel like there’s no happiness or hope in the situation.
examples: The teacher's grim expression made us realize we needed to take the test seriously and study harder.
In the story, the hero faced a grim challenge that tested his courage and strength against the evil dragon.
When the storm arrived, the sky looked grim, and we knew we had to stay indoors for safety.
After losing the game, my friend's grim face showed how disappointed he felt about not winning.
The old, abandoned house had a grim appearance, and we all felt a little scared to go inside.

meanings: A guardian is a person who looks after and keeps someone safe, like a parent or an adult who helps take care of a child.
examples: My grandma is my guardian, and she always makes sure I do my homework and eat healthy meals.
In our science class, we learned that a guardian can also be an animal protecting its young from danger.
When I play soccer, my coach acts as a guardian by teaching us the rules and helping us improve our skills.
In the book I read, the brave knight became the guardian of the kingdom, protecting it from dragons and other dangers.
During the camping trip, my dad was our guardian, making sure we stayed safe and followed all the rules around the campfire.

meanings: A hangar is a big building where airplanes are parked and fixed, just like a garage for cars.
examples: The airplane was safely parked inside the hangar, protected from the rain and wind outside.
During our field trip to the airport, we saw large planes resting in the hangar while mechanics worked on them.
My dad took me to the airshow, and I was amazed by how many planes fit in the big hangar.
In science class, we learned that a hangar is where planes get repairs and maintenance to keep flying safely.
When we visited the museum, we saw a vintage airplane displayed in a hangar that looked like it was from a movie.

meanings: A harbor is a safe place by the water where boats can park and stay protected from big waves and storms. It’s like a cozy garage for boats!
examples: The small fishing boats returned to the harbor after a long day of catching fish in the ocean.
In our science class, we learned that a harbor can protect boats from strong waves during a storm.
The adventurous children pretended their toy boats were sailing in a harbor as they played by the pond.
During our history lesson, we discovered that many famous cities were built near a harbor for trade.
My dad took me to see the big ships in the harbor, where they parked safely while waiting to unload their cargo.

meanings: Harsh means something that is very rough, uncomfortable, or unpleasant, like a loud noise or a mean comment.
examples: The teacher's criticism felt harsh when he pointed out all my mistakes on the project.
During the winter, the harsh winds made it difficult to ride my bike to school.
After the harsh sun burned my skin, I promised to wear sunscreen next time I went to the beach.
The harsh rules in the game made it hard for everyone to have fun while playing.
Some animals have to survive in harsh environments, like deserts where there's very little water.

meanings: Harvest is the time when farmers pick fully grown fruits, vegetables, and grains from their fields. It’s like gathering all the food that has been growing so it can be eaten or sold.
examples: Every fall, farmers gather their crops during the harvest to prepare for the winter months.
In science class, we learned how plants grow and when it's the best time to harvest fruits and vegetables.
During the harvest festival, our school had games and delicious food made from the crops picked by local farmers.
My grandparents invited us to their farm to help with the harvest, and we picked apples from the trees together.
The book we read told a story about a family who worked hard to harvest their corn before the first snow arrived.

meanings: Doing something very brave and strong, especially when it's hard or scary, like a superhero helping others.
examples: The firefighter made a heroic rescue when he saved a kitten stuck in a tree during the storm.
In the book, the young knight showed heroic bravery when he faced the dragon to protect his village.
During the game, my teammate made a heroic effort by scoring the winning goal even after being hurt.
The soldier’s heroic actions during the battle helped keep many people safe and earned him a medal of honor.
When my sister stood up to the bully at school, her courageous act was truly heroic and inspired others to be brave.

meanings: To cut or shape wood using a tool like an axe or a saw. For example, when someone is making a wooden chair, they might hew the pieces to the right size.
examples: The lumberjack had to hew the large tree into smaller pieces for the school project we were working on.
In art class, we learned how to hew a block of wood to create our very own sculptures.
When building a fort in the backyard, we used tools to hew the branches into the right shapes.
The story told how ancient people would hew stones to make tools for hunting and farming.
During our camping trip, we watched the ranger hew logs to make a bench for everyone to sit on.

meanings: Very funny; something that makes you laugh a lot.
examples: The movie we watched last night was so hilarious that we couldn't stop laughing the whole time.
During our school talent show, my friend's silly dance made everyone in the audience find it hilarious.
My little brother told a hilarious joke about a chicken crossing the road that made our whole family burst into laughter.
When we played charades at the sleepover, some of the guesses were so hilarious that we nearly fell off the couch!
In the comic book I read, the superhero's funny mistakes were so hilarious that I couldn't wait to read the next issue.

meanings: To hoist means to lift something up high, like when you raise a flag on a pole or help a friend lift a heavy box.
examples: To raise the flag high on the pole, we had to hoist it carefully during the school assembly.
When we went camping, we needed to hoist the heavy backpack onto my shoulders before hiking up the hill.
During gym class, we learned how to hoist the soccer net up so we could play a game.
The team worked together to hoist the giant trophy after winning the championship match.
In science class, we used a pulley to hoist a weight and see how it made lifting easier.

meanings: The horizon is the place where the sky looks like it meets the ground. When you look far away, especially at the ocean or a big field, that's where you can see the horizon.
examples: As I stood on the hill, I could see the sun setting at the horizon, painting the sky with beautiful colors.
In art class, we learned how to draw a landscape by adding a horizon line where the earth meets the sky.
During our nature walk, I spotted a mountain far away on the horizon, and it looked like a giant shadow.
When I read my favorite book, I imagined the hero standing on the horizon, ready for a new adventure to begin.
In science class, we talked about how the horizon looks different from the top of a tall building compared to the ground.

meanings: Hostile means being mean or unfriendly, like when someone doesn't want to be friends or is acting angry towards others.
examples: The dog barked loudly and seemed hostile when I tried to pet it without asking its owner first.
During the game, one team acted hostile by not playing fair and arguing with the referees.
In the story, the hero faced a hostile dragon that didn't want to share its treasure with anyone.
When the classmates teased each other, it created a hostile atmosphere that made everyone feel uncomfortable.
The teacher explained that being hostile to others can hurt their feelings and make it hard to be friends.

meanings: To huddle means to come together and stand close to each other, usually to keep warm or feel safe, like when friends gather under a blanket on a chilly day.
examples: During the chilly winter day, we all decided to huddle together under the big blanket to stay warm while watching a movie.
In soccer practice, the coach called us to huddle so he could explain the new strategy for our big game this weekend.
When the storm started, we huddled in the living room with our flashlights, telling spooky stories to keep ourselves entertained.
On the school trip, the students huddled together for a group photo in front of the giant tree at the park.
After the hike, we found a spot to huddle around the campfire, roasting marshmallows and sharing funny stories.

meanings: Not doing anything or not being busy; like when you have free time and choose to relax instead of working or playing.
examples: While waiting for my turn in the game, I sat idle on the bench and watched my friends play.
The plant in the corner of the room looked sad and idle because it hadn’t been watered in days.
When I’m idle during the weekend, I like to read books or draw pictures to keep myself busy.
The team felt idle after losing the game, but they promised to practice harder for the next match.
Even though my dog was idle on the couch, he still perked up when he heard the treat bag crinkle.

meanings: To light up a place or make something easier to understand, like when a lamp brightens a room or when someone helps you learn something new.
examples: The teacher used a flashlight to illuminate the dark corners of the classroom during our science experiment.
During our camping trip, the campfire helped illuminate the night sky, making it easier to see the stars.
The colorful pictures in the book helped to illuminate the story and make it more exciting for us.
When my mom explained the math problem, her clear explanations began to illuminate the tricky parts for me.
The streetlights illuminate the path when we walk home after playing soccer with our friends in the evening.

meanings: Very, very big or huge; much bigger than what you usually see.
examples: The immense mural on the school wall was painted by students, and it showed all the animals in the jungle.
When we visited the science museum, I saw an immense dinosaur skeleton that was taller than my dad!
The immense pile of leaves in my backyard was perfect for jumping into with my friends on a sunny afternoon.
In the library, I found an immense book about space that had pictures of planets and stars that amazed me.
During the soccer game, the immense crowd cheered loudly for our team, making us feel like champions!

meanings: Feeling angry or upset because you think something is unfair or not right, like if someone is treated badly when they didn’t deserve it.
examples: When the teacher unfairly gave everyone a bad grade, I felt indignant because I worked really hard on my project.
My sister was indignant when she saw that I used her favorite crayons without asking her first.
After losing the game because of a wrong call by the referee, the whole team felt indignant and wanted to talk to him.
I felt indignant when my friend didn’t let me join the game, even though there were plenty of spots available.
When the class voted to have pizza for lunch but then changed it to broccoli, I was indignant and expressed my feelings to my teacher.

meanings: To cause someone to feel pain or sadness, like when a bully hurts another kid or when you accidentally hurt a friend.
examples: When kids argue, they can inflict hurtful words that make their friends feel sad.
In the story, the villain tried to inflict fear in the village, but the heroes stood strong.
If we don't take care of our planet, pollution can inflict serious damage on the environment.
During the game, one player accidentally tried to inflict a penalty on the other team by being too rough.
The teacher explained that teasing someone can inflict emotional pain, and we should always be kind.

meanings: Very strong or powerful, like a bright light or a loud sound that makes you feel things strongly.
examples: The intense heat from the sun made us drink extra water during our soccer practice.
My favorite book has an intense mystery that kept me guessing until the very end.
The intense competition in the science fair motivated me to work really hard on my project.
During the intense thunderstorm, we all gathered in the living room and played games together.
The intense colors of the rainbow after the rain made our day feel extra special.

meanings: To stop something from getting to where it was going, like catching a ball before it hits the ground.
examples: The soccer player was able to intercept the ball before it reached the goal, stopping the other team from scoring.
In science class, we learned how some animals intercept signals to communicate with each other in the wild.
During our game of capture the flag, I tried to intercept my friend's flag before she could reach her base.
The detective was quick to intercept the message before it could be sent to the bad guy.
When I saw my little brother throw a toy, I rushed to intercept it so it wouldn't break anything in the living room.

meanings: To introduce means to tell someone your name or to show them something new for the first time.
examples: Today in class, our teacher will introduce us to a new science project about the solar system.
I want to introduce my best friend to my grandma because she loves meeting new people.
At the school assembly, the principal will introduce the new students to everyone in the audience.
When we start our book club, I will introduce the first book we will read together.
During soccer practice, the coach will introduce some new drills to help us improve our skills.

meanings: To look closely and ask questions about something to learn more about it or find out the truth.
examples: We will investigate the science project to find out why plants grow better in sunlight than in the dark.
The detective had to investigate the clues left behind to solve the mystery of the missing cookies.
During our history lesson, we decided to investigate how ancient Egyptians built their pyramids using only simple tools.
In our nature club, we will investigate the different types of birds that visit our schoolyard each day.
After hearing strange noises at night, my brother and I decided to investigate what was happening in the backyard.

meanings: A jest is a funny joke or remark that someone makes to make people laugh. It's like when you tell a silly story to your friends to make them smile!
examples: During lunch, my friend made a jest about our science project that made everyone laugh.
I told a jest about my dog chasing his tail, and my sister couldn't stop giggling.
In history class, our teacher made a jest about knights in shining armor that made learning fun.
During the game, I made a jest about our team’s silly dance moves, and everyone joined in.
My cousin told a jest about a sneaky squirrel stealing acorns, and we all burst out laughing.

meanings: To push or bump into someone when you are in a crowded place, like at a concert or a busy hallway.
examples: During the field trip, the kids began to jostle each other excitedly when they saw the huge dinosaur skeleton.
In the crowded cafeteria, I had to jostle my way through the tables to find a seat next to my best friend.
When the music started, everyone began to jostle around the dance floor, trying to find the perfect spot to show their moves.
As the soccer game kicked off, players jostled for the ball in a rush to score the first goal.
While we were hiking, I had to jostle past some branches that were blocking the trail to see the beautiful view.

meanings: Jubilation is a feeling of really, really happy excitement, like when you celebrate a big win or a special day with friends and family.
examples: When our school team won the championship game, the gym was filled with jubilation as everyone cheered and celebrated together.
The day of the science fair was full of jubilation, with students excitedly showing off their projects to parents and friends.
After finishing our big art project, we felt jubilation as we displayed our colorful paintings in the school hallway.
When the last school bell rang before summer vacation, the playground erupted in jubilation as kids ran outside to enjoy their break.
During the holiday party, the room was filled with jubilation as we sang songs, shared treats, and played games with our friends.

meanings: A jubilee is a big celebration that happens to mark an important anniversary, like a special birthday for a country or a group of people. It's a time for fun, parties, and remembering good times!
examples: Our school is planning a jubilee to celebrate its 50th anniversary, and everyone is excited to join the festivities.
During the town's jubilee, there were games, music, and delicious food for all the families to enjoy together.
My grandma told me stories about her jubilee when she turned 75, and how her friends surprised her with a big party.
In history class, we learned that a jubilee can mark important events, like a king's reign or a community's founding.
For my birthday this year, I want to have a jubilee theme with balloons and decorations to celebrate with all my friends.

meanings: Kin means your family members or relatives, like your parents, siblings, grandparents, and cousins. They are the people you are connected to by blood or marriage.
examples: My grandma always tells stories about our kin and how they lived many years ago.
During the family reunion, I met many of my kin who I had never seen before.
In science class, we learned that all humans are part of a larger kin group called "homo sapiens."
The book I read was about a brave knight who fought to protect his kin from danger.
At the picnic, we played games with our kin while enjoying delicious food together.

meanings: To set someone free from being trapped or controlled, like letting someone out of a cage or helping a friend who feels stuck.
examples: The brave soldiers worked together to liberate the town from the enemy and bring peace back to the people.
In the story, the hero's journey was to liberate the magical creatures trapped by the wicked sorcerer in his dark castle.
When the school decided to give students a voice in choosing lunch options, they helped liberate everyone from boring food choices.
The scientists aimed to liberate the animals in the lab by finding a way to protect them while still learning important information.
During the game, we worked as a team to liberate our captured flag from the other side of the field and win the match.

meanings: Likeness is when two things or people look or seem similar to each other, like how a puppy can look like its mother.
examples: The painting showed a likeness of the famous singer, making it easy to recognize her.
In our art class, we created portraits, trying to capture the likeness of our best friends.
The two puppies had a striking likeness, with the same floppy ears and big brown eyes.
When I saw the movie, the main character was a likeness of my favorite book hero, which made it exciting.
During history class, we learned that many ancient statues were made to show the likeness of important leaders.

meanings: To loathe something means to really, really dislike it or feel strong disgust for it, like when you think a certain food tastes bad or when someone is being very mean.
examples: I absolutely loathe doing my homework when I could be playing outside with my friends.
My brother loathes broccoli so much that he tries to hide it under his napkin at dinner.
Sometimes, I loathe waking up early on weekends when I just want to sleep in a little longer.
During gym class, I loathe running laps, but I love playing games like soccer afterward.
My sister loathes cleaning her room, especially when there are so many toys scattered everywhere.

meanings: Lumber is wood that has been cut into flat pieces or beams, which people use to build houses, furniture, and other things.
examples: The carpenter used lumber to build a strong treehouse where all of us could play together.
In science class, we learned how lumber comes from trees and is used to make furniture and houses.
When we visited a construction site, we saw workers carrying large pieces of lumber to build a new school.
My dad bought some lumber at the store to make a new picnic table for our backyard.
During the history lesson, we discovered that early settlers used lumber to build their homes and farms.

meanings: To lurch means to move suddenly and in a shaky way, like when you trip or lose your balance while walking.
examples: When the school bus hit a bump, we all felt it lurch to one side, making us giggle.
As I rode my bike down the hill, I had to quickly steer to avoid a lurch that could make me fall.
The puppy started to lurch forward when it saw the squirrel running across the yard.
During the science experiment, the table began to lurch, causing all the beakers to wobble dangerously.
When the roller coaster reached the top of the hill, it gave us a sudden lurch that made everyone scream with excitement!

meanings: To attract someone or something by offering something they want, like a toy or a treat. For example, you might lure a pet with a snack to get them to come to you.
examples: The fisherman used shiny bait to lure the fish closer to his boat on the lake.
In the story, the clever fox tried to lure the chickens away from the farmyard.
During science class, we learned how flowers lure bees with their bright colors and sweet scents.
The magician’s tricks always lure the audience’s attention, making everyone gasp in surprise.
My mom baked cookies to lure my brother into helping her clean the kitchen.

meanings: Major means something that is very important or big. For example, a major event is one that lots of people think is special.
examples: Studying for the major test next week is important, so I need to make sure I review all my notes carefully.
The major project in art class will help us learn about famous painters and their styles.
During our school assembly, we learned about a major event in history that changed how people live today.
My favorite sport is soccer, and winning the major tournament this year would be a big achievement for our team.
Planting trees is a major way we can help protect the environment and make our planet healthier.

meanings: Makeshift means something that is thrown together quickly using what you have on hand, like using a cardboard box as a table for a short time. It's not meant to last forever.
examples: When the rain started, we used a makeshift roof made of a tarp to stay dry during the picnic.
During our science project, we built a makeshift volcano using a plastic bottle and some vinegar.
We created a makeshift fort in the living room with blankets and chairs for our indoor camping adventure.
Our team used a makeshift goal made of cones and shoes to play soccer in the park.
When the power went out, we made a makeshift lantern using a jar and a candle to light up the room.

meanings: The maximum is the highest number or amount that something can reach. For example, if a jar can hold 10 candies, then 10 is the maximum number of candies it can hold.
examples: In science class, we learned that the maximum temperature for boiling water is 100 degrees Celsius.
During gym class, we can only have a maximum of twenty students in the basketball game at a time.
The teacher told us that the maximum number of pages for our book reports is three.
My mom said I can have a maximum of two cookies after dinner to keep my tummy healthy.
When we went to the amusement park, the maximum height to ride the roller coaster was 48 inches.

meanings: Meager means having very little of something, like a small amount of food on your plate or not enough money to buy what you need.
examples: The meager lunch I packed for school only had a small sandwich and an apple, so I was still hungry by lunchtime.
After searching for hours, we found a meager amount of berries in the garden, just enough for a small snack.
The meager prize we won in the game was a sticker, but we were still proud of our teamwork.
On the meager shelf in the library, there were only a few books about dinosaurs, but I loved reading them anyway.
His meager collection of baseball cards had only three, but he treasured each one like it was a rare gem.

meanings: To get involved in someone else's business when you shouldn't, like butting in on a friend's argument instead of letting them solve it themselves.
examples: It's not nice to meddle in someone else's game when they are trying to play by their own rules.
When my little brother tried to meddle in my art project, I asked him to let me work alone.
I told my friend not to meddle in my secrets because I wanted to keep them private.
During the group project, it was hard for everyone to focus when one person kept trying to meddle in others' ideas.
If you meddle with the science experiment too much, it might not turn out the way we want it to!

meanings: Doing things in a careful and organized way, like following steps in a recipe to make sure everything turns out right.
examples: When I organize my school supplies, I use a methodical approach so I can find everything I need quickly.
The scientist was methodical in her experiments, carefully noting each step to see what worked best.
During the soccer game, the coach gave methodical instructions to help us improve our teamwork on the field.
My mom has a methodical way of cleaning the house, starting from one room and moving to the next without missing anything.
In art class, I like to be methodical about my drawings, planning out each part before I start coloring.

meanings: To mimic means to copy what someone else does or says, often in a funny way. It's like pretending to be someone else for fun!
examples: During recess, my friend can mimic our teacher's funny dance moves, and everyone laughs.
In art class, we learned how to mimic the colors of a sunset using different paints.
My little brother loves to mimic the sounds of animals, especially the barking of our dog.
When we played charades, I had to mimic a monkey, and it made everyone giggle.
At the science fair, I created a robot that could mimic human movements, which amazed all the judges.

meanings: Minor" means something that is not very important or is smaller than other things. For example, a minor problem is one that is easy to fix and doesn't need a lot of attention.
examples: The teacher said that finishing the project on time was important, but fixing minor mistakes could wait until after lunch.
During the soccer game, I scored a goal, but my friend made a minor mistake by passing the ball to the wrong player.
In our science class, we learned about major planets, but we also talked about minor moons that orbit around them.
While cleaning my room, I found some minor messes that needed fixing, like a few toys out of place and some books left open.
The story had a few minor details that changed, but the main plot stayed the same and was still really interesting.

meanings: Mirth is a feeling of happiness and fun that makes you want to laugh and smile, like when you're having a great time with friends.
examples: The children erupted in mirth when the clown made silly faces at the birthday party.
As we played the game, our mirth filled the room, making everyone laugh and have a great time.
Reading the funny story brought us so much mirth that we couldn't stop giggling together.
During the school talent show, the audience's mirth was contagious as each act made them laugh.
We shared jokes at lunch, and the mirth around the table made it the best part of our day.

meanings: Mischief is playful behavior that causes trouble or annoys others, like when a friend plays a funny prank or makes a silly mess.
examples: The puppy got into mischief by digging up the garden and scattering dirt everywhere.
During recess, my friends and I created some mischief by hiding each other's backpacks as a funny surprise.
When I tried to bake cookies, my little sister caused some mischief by sneaking chocolate chips before I could use them.
In the classroom, the students made mischief by whispering jokes to each other while the teacher was writing on the board.
My brother's mischief made me laugh when he dressed our cat in a funny hat for a silly picture.

meanings: Molten means something, like metal or rock, that has been heated so much that it turns into a hot, flowing liquid.
examples: The volcano erupted and sent molten lava flowing down its side, creating new land as it cooled.
In science class, we learned that molten metal is poured into molds to create cool shapes like statues and tools.
The molten chocolate in the fondue pot was perfect for dipping strawberries during our dessert party.
When you heat sand in a furnace, it can become molten glass that can be shaped into beautiful art.
The story about ancient Rome mentioned how people used molten bronze to make strong weapons and fancy decorations.

meanings: Very big and scary, like a giant creature from a story or a movie. It can also mean something that is strange or not normal.
examples: The monstrous dinosaur in the museum looked so big that it could almost reach the ceiling.
In the story, the hero faced a monstrous dragon that breathed fire and guarded treasure.
During the science fair, my project about a monstrous black hole amazed everyone with its size and mystery.
When we went camping, we heard monstrous sounds in the night that made us feel a little scared.
My little brother built a monstrous sandcastle at the beach that towered over all the other kids' creations.

meanings: A moral is a lesson that tells us what is right and wrong, usually learned from stories or real-life situations. It helps us understand how to be good and make the right choices.
examples: The story of the tortoise and the hare teaches a moral about how slow and steady can win the race.
In our class, we learned a moral from the book about honesty: it's always best to tell the truth.
After playing soccer, my coach told us the moral of teamwork is that we achieve more when we work together.
In science class, we discussed the moral of protecting nature and how it helps the planet stay healthy for everyone.
The moral of the fable was that being kind to others can lead to friendship and happiness.

meanings: A morsel is a tiny piece of food, like a small bite of cookie or a little bit of fruit. It's something you can easily eat in one bite!
examples: I took a small morsel of chocolate cake from my plate and savored its rich flavor.
During lunch, I shared a morsel of my sandwich with my friend who forgot his lunch at home.
At the picnic, I enjoyed a morsel of fruit salad that was filled with strawberries and blueberries.
The puppy eagerly gobbled up each morsel of his dinner, wagging his tail happily.
When we read the story, I imagined a tiny morsel of bread floating down the river with the hungry duck.

meanings: To navigate means to find your way from one place to another, like using a map or following signs when you're going on a trip.
examples: I used a map to navigate through the forest and find the hidden treasure with my friends.
In gym class, we had to navigate the obstacle course without touching the ground.
When we played the video game, I had to navigate my character through tricky levels and avoid enemies.
During our field trip, the teacher helped us navigate the museum so we could see all the cool exhibits.
I learned how to navigate my bicycle around the park safely while riding with my friends.

meanings: To negotiate means to talk with someone to find a way to agree on something, like sharing toys or deciding what game to play.
examples: I had to negotiate with my parents about which video game to buy for my birthday.
During the group project, we needed to negotiate who would do each part of the work to finish on time.
My sister and I tried to negotiate a deal to share the last cookie without arguing over it.
The soccer team had to negotiate the rules for our practice game so everyone could have fun.
When planning a picnic, we will negotiate where to go and what snacks to bring to please everyone.

meanings: Nonchalant means to act calm and relaxed, even when something big is happening. It's like when you stay cool and not worried during a test or a game.
examples: Even though he lost the game, Jacob remained nonchalant and congratulated the winner with a smile.
When the teacher announced a surprise quiz, Sarah was nonchalant, knowing she had studied hard.
During the school play, Mia felt nonchalant as she walked on stage, ready to perform her lines.
Even when it started to rain, the kids were nonchalant and kept playing outside without a care.
After finishing his book report, Leo was nonchalant about waiting for his turn to present in class.

meanings: Nostalgia is a feeling you get when you remember happy times from the past and wish you could experience them again. It’s like looking at old photos and feeling warm and smiley inside.
examples: When I hear the old song from my childhood, it fills me with nostalgia for the fun times I had with my friends.
Looking at my baby photos brings a sense of nostalgia, reminding me of all the silly moments from when I was younger.
Reading my favorite book again gives me nostalgia, as I remember how excited I felt the first time I discovered the story.
Every time I visit my old school, I feel a wave of nostalgia for all the laughter and adventures I had there.
Playing the video games I loved as a kid brings back nostalgia, reminding me of the weekends I spent with my siblings.

meanings: Notable" means something that is special or important and deserves to be noticed, like a big achievement or a famous person.
examples: The notable painting in the art museum caught my eye because it was so colorful and full of life.
During the science fair, my project on volcanoes received a notable award for being the most creative.
My teacher told us that the notable author we studied wrote many famous books that kids love to read.
At the basketball game, my friend made a notable three-point shot that helped our team win!
In history class, we learned about a notable leader who changed the world with his brave actions.

meanings: Numerous means having a lot of something, like when you see many stars in the sky or a big group of friends at school.
examples: There are numerous stars in the night sky that twinkle and make it look magical.
In our science class, we learned about the numerous types of plants that grow in the rainforest.
My soccer team has numerous fans who cheer for us at every game, making us feel really special.
The library has numerous books about adventure, and I can't wait to read them all this summer.
During the field trip, we saw numerous animals at the zoo, including lions, elephants, and colorful birds.

meanings: An oasis is a green place in a desert where water is found. It helps plants and animals live and is a nice spot for travelers to rest.
examples: After walking through the hot desert, we finally spotted an oasis with tall palm trees and sparkling water.
In the middle of the dry desert, the oasis was a magical place where animals and plants could thrive.
During our nature hike, we learned that an oasis can be a safe haven for travelers and wildlife in harsh conditions.
The storybook told us about a brave explorer who discovered an oasis filled with delicious fruits and fresh water.
When we played outside in the sun, the shady tree by the pond felt like an oasis on a hot summer day.

meanings: Obedient means listening to and following rules or instructions from someone, like a parent or teacher.
examples: The obedient dog followed every command, which made it easy for its owner to teach it new tricks.
In class, the obedient students listened carefully to the teacher and completed their assignments on time.
My little brother is very obedient when Mom asks him to help set the table for dinner.
During soccer practice, the obedient players listened to their coach and worked hard to improve their skills.
The obedient garden plants grew tall and healthy because I watered them every day, just like my science project suggested.

meanings: Something that is not well known or is hard to see or understand, like a hidden treasure that only a few people know about.
examples: The book we found in the library was about an obscure animal that very few people have ever heard of.
During history class, we learned about an obscure event that happened long ago and changed the world in a surprising way.
My teacher told us about an obscure artist whose paintings are not famous but are still very beautiful and interesting.
While playing the trivia game, I struggled to answer an obscure question about a science fact that I had never heard before.
In our nature hike, we spotted an obscure plant that only grows in a few special places around our town.

meanings: No longer used or needed because something newer or better has come along, like an old toy that kids don't play with anymore.
examples: The old typewriter in the attic is now obsolete since everyone uses computers to write.
Many toys from the past, like yo-yos and marbles, seem obsolete to kids who love video games.
In science class, we learned that floppy disks are obsolete because we now use USB drives for storage.
Some old video game consoles are becoming obsolete, making way for new gaming systems with better graphics.
The way we used to send letters by mail is becoming obsolete because we can now send messages instantly online.

meanings: An obstacle is something that makes it hard to get to where you want to go or to do what you want to do, like a big rock in your path when you're riding your bike.
examples: When we played soccer, a big puddle on the field became an obstacle that made it hard to score a goal.
In science class, we learned that mountains can be an obstacle for animals trying to find food and water.
While building my model rocket, I faced an obstacle when the glue wouldn’t hold the pieces together.
My friends and I had to find a way around the obstacle of a fallen tree on our nature hike.
In the story, the brave knight faced many obstacles on his journey to rescue the princess from the dragon.

meanings: An occasion is a special time or event when something important happens, like a birthday party or a holiday celebration.
examples: We celebrate special occasions like birthdays and holidays with cake, presents, and lots of fun.
On one occasion, I helped my mom bake cookies for our school bake sale, and they turned out delicious!
During our science fair, each student had the occasion to showcase their cool projects to everyone in the school.
We usually go camping in the summer, but this occasion was extra special because we invited our friends to join us.
My teacher told us that the school will have an occasion to celebrate our hard work at the end of the year with a big party!

meanings: To oppose means to disagree with something or to try to stop it from happening. For example, if your friend wants to play a game you don’t like, you might oppose their idea.
examples: Some students chose to oppose the new school rules because they felt they were too strict.
In our science class, we learned that animals can oppose changes in their environment to survive.
My brother likes to oppose my ideas when we play games, but I always try to convince him otherwise.
During the debate, I had to oppose my classmate's opinion about the best way to help the environment.
When my friends wanted to play soccer, I had to oppose them because I wanted to play basketball instead.

meanings: An optimist is a person who always looks on the bright side and believes that good things will happen, even when things get tough.
examples: My dad is such an optimist; he always believes we can win the soccer game no matter how tough the other team is.
Even when the weather is rainy, my sister is an optimist and says it will be sunny tomorrow for our picnic.
In class, my teacher is an optimist who encourages us to try our best, even when we find the math problems difficult.
When I lost my favorite toy, my friend, who is an optimist, told me we would find it again soon if we looked together.
Reading stories with happy endings makes me an optimist, because I love believing that everything will turn out well in the end.

meanings: An option is a choice you can make when you have different things to pick from, like deciding what game to play or what snack to eat.
examples: In art class, we had the option to paint or draw, and I chose to paint a beautiful sunset.
When picking a book to read, I had the option to choose a mystery or a fantasy story, and I picked the mystery.
For lunch, I had the option of a sandwich or a salad, so I decided to try the salad today.
During gym class, we could choose the option of playing soccer or basketball, and I picked soccer because I love it.
When planning our field trip, the teacher gave us the option to visit a zoo or a science museum, and everyone voted for the zoo.

meanings: The outskirts are the parts of a city or town that are farthest away from the center, where there are usually fewer buildings and more open spaces like parks and farms.
examples: The new playground was built on the outskirts of the city, making it a quiet place to play.
When we went hiking with our class, we explored the forests on the outskirts of town.
The animal shelter is located on the outskirts, where there is more space for the animals to run.
My grandparents live on the outskirts of the city, where there are lots of gardens and fresh air.
During our field trip, we learned about the farms that are found on the outskirts of the busy city.

meanings: Something that is late or not done by the time it was supposed to be, like returning a library book after the due date.
examples: My library book is overdue, so I need to return it before I get a fine.
The project for school is overdue, and I have to finish it this weekend to avoid losing points.
I realized my homework was overdue when the teacher reminded us about it in class.
The game we ordered online is overdue, and I hope it arrives before my birthday party.
The plants in the garden are overdue for watering, so I need to help my mom today.

meanings: To remove a leader or group in charge, usually by using force or fighting, because people want a change.
examples: The knights planned to overthrow the evil king in the story we read during class.
In our history lesson, we learned how people tried to overthrow the unfair ruler many years ago.
The soccer team hoped to overthrow the champions and win the trophy this season.
In the movie, the animals banded together to overthrow the bad farmer and take back their farm.
The students decided to overthrow the boring school rules by suggesting fun new ones during the meeting.

meanings: Doing something very carefully and with a lot of effort, making sure to pay attention to every little detail.
examples: The artist spent painstaking hours creating a beautiful mural that covered the entire wall of our school.
My science project required painstaking research, but I learned so much about planets and stars.
Our teacher gave us a painstaking assignment to write a detailed story, and I worked on it every day after school.
The gardener was painstaking as he planted each flower, making sure they were in the right spot to grow beautifully.
During the history project, I did painstaking work to find old pictures and facts about my town’s past.

meanings: To pardon someone means to forgive them for making a mistake or doing something wrong, like when you say it's okay after a friend accidentally bumps into you.
examples: I accidentally knocked over my friend's drink, so I quickly said, "Pardon me for that mistake!"
When I forgot to return my library book on time, the librarian kindly said, "I pardon you this time."
During the game, I accidentally stepped on my teammate's foot, and I asked, "Can you pardon me for that?"
If you bump into someone while playing, it's polite to say, "Pardon me!" to show you are sorry.
When I made a mistake in my math homework, my teacher smiled and said, "I pardon you; it happens to everyone."

meanings: A pasture is a field covered with grass where animals, like cows and sheep, can eat and roam around. It's like a big grassy playground for these animals!
examples: The cows were happily grazing in the green pasture near the barn, munching on the fresh grass.
During our field trip, we saw horses running freely in the sunny pasture behind the farmhouse.
In science class, we learned that a pasture is important for animals like sheep and goats to eat and grow strong.
My grandpa has a big pasture where he keeps his sheep, and I love visiting to help feed them.
When we went hiking, we found a beautiful pasture filled with colorful wildflowers and buzzing bees.

meanings: Being patient means waiting calmly for something you want or for a problem to get better, even if it takes a long time. It's like when you have to wait in line or wait for your turn without getting up...
examples: When my little brother is upset, I try to be patient and help him feel better.
During art class, I had to be patient while waiting for my turn to use the paintbrush.
My mom always says that being patient while learning something new will help me get better at it.
While fishing at the lake, I learned that being patient is important because the fish might take a while to bite.
In soccer practice, I must be patient when I don’t score a goal right away and keep trying my best.

meanings: A pedestrian is a person who is walking, usually on a sidewalk or street in a city or town.
examples: The pedestrian walked carefully across the street, following the traffic signals to stay safe.
During our field trip, we saw many pedestrians enjoying the sunny weather in the city park.
The teacher explained that a pedestrian is someone who walks, especially near busy roads and sidewalks.
When we go to the mall, we always look out for pedestrians to make sure everyone is safe.
In our neighborhood, we often see pedestrians jogging or walking their dogs in the early morning.

meanings: To go into or through something, like when a pencil goes through a piece of paper.
examples: The rain was so heavy that it could penetrate the ground and help the plants grow.
When we built our fort, we used blankets to cover the walls and make sure no light could penetrate inside.
In science class, we learned how the roots of trees can penetrate the soil to find water and nutrients.
During our nature walk, I saw a tiny insect that could penetrate the thick bark of a tree to find food.
The superhero's special powers allowed him to penetrate the enemy's defenses and save the day.

meanings: To perish means to die or to go away completely. For example, a plant can perish if it doesn't get enough water and sunlight.
examples: If we don't water the plants, they might perish and become dry and brown.
In the winter, some animals hibernate so they don't perish in the cold weather.
The old book was left outside and began to perish because of the rain and sun.
If we don't take care of the ocean, many sea creatures could perish due to pollution.
During the science experiment, we learned that flowers can perish without enough sunlight.

meanings: To become so scared that you can’t move or speak, like when you see a scary monster in a movie.
examples: The loud thunderstorm seemed to petrify my little brother, and he hid under the blanket until it was over.
When I saw the giant spider in the corner of the room, it petrified me, and I couldn't move for a moment.
The scary movie was so intense that it petrified my friends, and we all jumped when the monster appeared.
During the school play, I was petrified when I forgot my lines, and I stood frozen on stage for a few seconds.
The ghost story my teacher told us was so spooky it petrified the whole class, leaving us too scared to speak.

meanings: A pledge is a strong promise to do something important or to help someone. It's like saying, "I promise I will!" and really meaning it.
examples: I made a pledge to my teacher that I would always do my homework on time and help my classmates.
Before the soccer game, our team took a pledge to play fair and support each other, no matter the score.
During the assembly, we all took a pledge to keep our school clean and recycle whenever we can.
I wrote a pledge to read for at least twenty minutes every night to improve my reading skills.
My friend and I made a pledge to help each other practice our spelling words for the upcoming test.

meanings: The population is the total number of people who live in a certain place, like a town, city, or country. It helps us understand how many people are around us in our community.
examples: The population of our town is growing because more families are moving here for new jobs and schools.
In science class, we learned that the population of penguins in Antarctica is decreasing due to climate change.
The population of students at our school has increased, so we now have more teachers and classes to help us learn.
When we studied history, we discovered that the population of ancient Rome was much larger than we thought.
During our nature walk, we counted the population of different bird species in the park and noted how many we saw.

meanings: A portrait is a picture of a person that shows their face. It can be a drawing, painting, or photograph that helps us remember what they look like.
examples: My art teacher asked us to create a portrait of someone we admire, like a family member or a famous person.
In history class, we learned about famous artists who painted beautiful portraits of kings and queens from long ago.
I took a photograph of my friend for a school project, and it turned out to be a great portrait!
At the museum, I saw a stunning portrait of a woman that made me wonder about her life and story.
For my birthday, my mom gave me a portrait of my dog, and I hung it on my bedroom wall.

meanings: To predict means to guess what will happen in the future based on clues or things you already know, like when you think it might rain because you see dark clouds.
examples: I can predict that if we water the plants every day, they will grow bigger and healthier.
In science class, we learned how to predict the weather using clouds and temperature.
My teacher asked us to predict what would happen to the story's characters if they made different choices.
During the basketball game, I could predict that our team would win if we kept practicing hard.
When I read the book, I tried to predict the ending based on the clues the author gave us.

meanings: A prelude is something that happens at the beginning of a story, song, or event to help prepare us for what comes next. It's like the warm-up before a big game!
examples: The loud music played as a prelude to the school's talent show, making everyone excited for the performances.
In the book I read, the prelude gave a sneak peek of the adventure that was about to unfold.
The coach said the warm-up exercises were a prelude to the big game, helping us get ready to play our best.
The sunrise was a beautiful prelude to the fun day we had planned at the beach with our friends.
Before the science fair began, the teacher gave a prelude about the importance of teamwork and creativity in our projects.

meanings: Premature means something that happens too early or before the right time, like a baby being born before it is ready.
examples: The flowers bloomed prematurely this spring because the weather got warm too early.
My teacher said it was premature to celebrate our project being done since we still need to present it.
We found a baby bird that had fallen from its nest, but it was too premature to fly on its own.
It felt premature to start the movie before all the popcorn was popped and ready to eat.
My little brother tried to ride his bike without training wheels, but it was premature since he wasn't ready yet.

meanings: To preserve means to keep something safe and in good condition so it doesn't get ruined or go bad. For example, when you put fruit in the refrigerator to keep it fresh, you are preserving it.
examples: We should preserve our natural parks so that everyone can enjoy the beautiful trees and animals for many years to come.
My grandma taught me how to preserve fruits by making delicious jams that we can enjoy all year round.
In science class, we learned that scientists work hard to preserve endangered species, like the panda, to help them survive.
To preserve the history of our town, we visited the museum and looked at old photos and artifacts from the past.
I like to preserve my favorite books by keeping them on a special shelf and reading them carefully so they don’t get damaged.

meanings: Previous" means something that happened before now or before another event. For example, if you watched a movie last week, that movie is the previous one you saw.
examples: The previous lesson in math helped me understand how to solve the new problems today.
I remembered the previous chapter of the book had a big surprise that I didn't expect.
During the science fair, my project was better than my previous one because I learned from my mistakes.
The previous game we played was so much fun that we decided to play it again this weekend.
My sister showed me her previous drawings, and I could see how much she has improved in art.

meanings: Prey is an animal that another animal catches and eats for food. For example, a rabbit is prey for a fox.
examples: A lion hunts for its prey in the tall grass of the savannah, using its speed and strength to catch dinner.
In the ocean, a shark looks for small fish as its prey, swimming swiftly to catch them in its sharp teeth.
During our nature walk, we learned that owls are skilled hunters that search for their prey, like mice and small rabbits, at night.
The hawk soared high above the trees, scanning the ground for any sign of prey to swoop down and catch.
In the animal kingdom, the balance of nature relies on predators finding prey to survive and keep the ecosystem healthy.

meanings: Primitive" means something that is very simple or basic, often like how things were a long time ago before they became more advanced. For example, a primitive tool might be a simple stone used for cut...
examples: The cave drawings from ancient people are examples of primitive art that show how they lived a long time ago.
In science class, we learned that primitive tools like stone axes were used by early humans for hunting and building.
When we visit the museum, we can see how primitive homes were made from branches and mud before houses like ours existed.
Playing with sticks and rocks can be a fun way to experience primitive games that children played hundreds of years ago.
My history book explained how primitive societies had to rely on nature for food and shelter before modern conveniences were invented.

meanings: To go forward with something, like starting or continuing an activity or task.
examples: After the teacher explained the math problem, we were ready to proceed with our classwork.
When the rain stopped, we decided to proceed with our outdoor picnic at the park.
Once everyone finished their presentations, we could proceed to the fun part of the science fair.
My coach said we should proceed with our soccer practice even though it was a little chilly outside.
Before we could start reading our new book, the librarian reminded us to proceed quietly to the reading area.

meanings: To proclaim means to announce something important to everyone, like when a teacher tells the class about a special event.
examples: The principal will proclaim the winner of the science fair during the assembly next week.
During the school play, Emma will proclaim her character's important message to the audience.
At the end of the game, the coach will proclaim our team's victory over the rival school.
On Earth Day, we will proclaim our promise to help keep our planet clean and healthy.
In the story, the king will proclaim a holiday to celebrate the heroes of the kingdom.

meanings: To prohibit means to say that something is not allowed. For example, if a school prohibits running in the hallways, it means students should walk instead.
examples: The school decided to prohibit running in the hallways to keep everyone safe during class changes.
My parents prohibit me from using my tablet before finishing my homework so I can focus better.
The rules of the game prohibit players from talking during the round to make it more challenging.
During the science experiment, the teacher will prohibit us from touching the chemicals without wearing gloves.
The park signs prohibit littering, reminding everyone to keep nature clean and beautiful for all to enjoy.

meanings: Prone means likely to be affected by something, especially in a way that is not good. For example, if someone is prone to getting colds, they often get sick easily.
examples: Some kids are prone to getting colds when the weather changes from warm to cold.
After falling off his bike, Jake realized he was prone to accidents when he rides too fast.
Lily is prone to losing her homework if she doesn’t keep her backpack organized.
During the rainy season, the river is prone to flooding, so we should be careful near the banks.
My dog is prone to barking loudly whenever he sees a squirrel in the yard.

meanings: To prosper means to do really well in life, like getting good grades in school, having fun with friends, or having enough money for the things you need.
examples: If we all work together on our group project, our team will prosper and get a great grade.
In the garden, the flowers will prosper if we water them regularly and give them plenty of sunlight.
When we practice hard for the soccer tournament, our team is sure to prosper and win the championship.
If you take care of your pet and feed it well, your pet will prosper and be very happy.
Reading lots of books can help your mind prosper and learn new things about the world around you.

meanings: To stick out or go beyond something, like how a tree branch can stick out from a trunk or how a person's head might stick out from behind a door.
examples: The tree's branches protrude over the path, making it hard to walk without ducking.
During art class, I used clay to make a sculpture with shapes that protrude from the base.
The dog’s ears protrude from its fluffy fur, making it look even cuter when it tilts its head.
In science class, we learned that some rocks can protrude from the ground, creating interesting shapes.
The building's windows protrude slightly, giving it a unique design that we all noticed on our field trip.

meanings: To give something that someone needs or wants, like food, toys, or help.
examples: The teacher will provide us with all the supplies we need for our science project next week.
During the winter, my dad will provide extra blankets to keep us warm at night.
The library can provide many exciting books for us to read over the summer break.
My coach will provide tips on how to improve my soccer skills during practice on Saturdays.
When we go camping, my mom will provide food and drinks for everyone to enjoy.

meanings: To make someone feel a strong emotion, like anger or excitement, by saying or doing something.
examples: Sometimes, teasing someone can provoke them to feel upset or angry, which is why it's important to be kind.
In science class, the teacher showed us an experiment that can provoke a chemical reaction using baking soda and vinegar.
When my little brother makes a mess in my room, it can provoke me to get really frustrated and ask him to clean up.
In soccer, if a player tries to trip you on purpose, it can provoke a strong reaction from you and your teammates.
When I read a book with a mean character, it can provoke feelings of anger and make me cheer for the hero even more.

meanings: Something that is puny is very small or weak compared to other things. For example, a tiny ant might be puny next to a big dog.
examples: The little ant looked puny next to the giant leaf it was trying to carry.
During gym class, I thought my basketball was puny compared to the huge ones my friends had.
When I saw the tiny puppy, I couldn't believe how puny it was compared to my big dog at home.
In the science project, my puny volcano erupted just a little, while the others exploded with lots of foam!
I felt puny standing next to the tall roller coaster, but I was still excited to ride it.

meanings: To purchase something means to buy it, usually by giving money in exchange for the item you want.
examples: I saved my allowance to make a special purchase of a new book about dinosaurs.
When we went to the store, my mom made a purchase of fresh fruits and vegetables for our meals.
During the school fair, I decided to purchase some colorful stickers to decorate my notebook.
My sister wanted to purchase a new video game, so she worked hard to earn extra chores around the house.
At the museum, we learned that people used to purchase things with shiny shells before money was invented.

meanings: To follow or chase after something you want, like a goal or a dream, and try hard to get it.
examples: I decided to pursue my dream of becoming an artist by practicing drawing every day after school.
During the science fair, I chose to pursue a project about how plants grow in different kinds of light.
My brother wants to pursue a spot on the soccer team, so he practices kicking the ball every afternoon.
In the library, I found a book about astronauts that inspired me to pursue a career in space exploration.
When I saw how fast my friend could run, I wanted to pursue my goal of becoming a better runner too.

meanings: To help someone feel better when they are scared or worried, so they know everything will be okay.
examples: My teacher tried to reassure us that the test would be easy if we studied hard.
When I was scared of the dark, my mom would come in to reassure me everything was okay.
Before the soccer game, my coach spoke to us to reassure the team that we could win.
I read a book about space, and it reassured me that astronauts wear special suits to stay safe.
When my friend was nervous about the school play, I told her I would be there to reassure her.

meanings: A rebel is a person who does not follow the rules or traditions and wants to change things that they think are unfair. They might stand up for what they believe in, even if it means going against othe...
examples: When the teacher asked us to follow the rules, Max decided to be a rebel and made up his own game instead.
In the story, the main character is a rebel who stands up against the unfair rules of the kingdom to help his friends.
During the school play, Sarah played the role of a rebel who challenged the king's orders and fought for justice.
Although my little brother is usually nice, he can be a rebel when he refuses to clean his room like our parents asked.
In history class, we learned about the famous rebel who led the fight for freedom and inspired many people to stand up for their rights.

meanings: A refuge is a safe place where people can go to feel protected from danger or trouble. It's like a cozy shelter where you can be safe and comfortable.
examples: During the storm, we found refuge in the school gym where it was safe and warm.
The little bird took refuge in the tree to escape from the strong wind and rain.
After hiking for hours, we found a cozy cave that served as our refuge from the chilly evening air.
In the story, the hero sought refuge in a hidden castle to protect himself from the evil dragon.
When I feel sad, my room becomes my refuge, where I can read and listen to music quietly.

meanings: To rule as a king or queen, making important decisions for a country or kingdom.
examples: In history class, we learned about how Queen Elizabeth II began her reign in 1952 and ruled for many years.
The kingdom in our storybook was peaceful during the king's reign, and everyone loved living there.
During the school election, my friend said she wanted to reign as class president to help organize fun events.
In the game we played, the player who won the most points would reign as the champion until the next round.
The butterfly's reign over the garden was short, but it brought joy to everyone who saw its beautiful colors.

meanings: Not wanting to do something; feeling unsure or not excited about it. For example, you might be reluctant to try a new food you’ve never tasted before.
examples: I was reluctant to try the new food at lunch because it looked different from what I usually eat.
When the teacher asked us to give a speech in class, I felt a little reluctant to speak in front of everyone.
My dog was reluctant to go outside in the rain, but I knew he needed to take his walk.
At first, I was reluctant to join the soccer team, but I ended up making new friends and having lots of fun.
Even though I was reluctant to read the thick book, I discovered it had an amazing story that I loved.

meanings: Remote" means something that is far away or not close to where you are, like a place you can’t easily reach, such as a distant island or a cabin in the woods.
examples: The remote island was so far away that we could only visit it by boat once a year.
In my science class, we learned that some animals live in remote places where people rarely go.
The ancient ruins were discovered in a remote valley, hidden from the world for many centuries.
During our camping trip, we found a remote spot by the river that was perfect for setting up our tents.
My grandma lives in a remote area, so we always look forward to visiting her during the holidays.

meanings: To need something for a specific purpose or to make something happen. For example, you might require a pencil to do your homework.
examples: To bake a cake, you require flour, sugar, eggs, and some special frosting to make it delicious.
Many sports require practice and teamwork to help everyone play their best during the game.
In science class, we learned that plants require sunlight and water to grow healthy and strong.
To complete your homework on time, you require a quiet place to focus and all your school supplies.
The animal shelter requires volunteers to help take care of the dogs and cats looking for a home.

meanings: To look like someone or something else, or to have similar features. For example, you might resemble a parent if you have the same hair or smile.
examples: My sister and I resemble each other so much that people often think we are twins, even though we are not.
The clouds in the sky resemble fluffy cotton candy, making me wish I could eat them!
In art class, we learned that some colors can resemble each other, like blue and green, which are both cool colors.
When I looked at the family photo, I noticed that my dog resembles my dad because they both have the same smile.
The leaves on the trees in autumn resemble a rainbow, with bright reds, yellows, and oranges everywhere I look.

meanings: To restrict means to stop or limit something from happening or being as big as it could be. For example, your parents might restrict your screen time, meaning you can only use devices for a little whi...
examples: The teacher decided to restrict the number of students allowed to join the club so everyone could have a chance to participate.
To keep the playground safe, the rules restrict running near the swings and slides during recess.
My parents restrict my screen time during the week, so I can spend more time reading and doing homework.
The coach will restrict our practice time if we don't listen and follow the team's rules during games.
In science class, we learned that laws can restrict how much pollution factories can release into the air to protect our planet.

meanings: To start doing something again after stopping for a while, like picking up a game after taking a break.
examples: After the rain stopped, we decided to resume our soccer game on the field.
When the bell rang, we will resume our math lesson after lunch in the classroom.
After taking a short break, the scientists will resume their important experiments in the lab.
Once everyone finished their snacks, we were ready to resume watching our favorite movie.
After the storm passed, we could finally resume our nature walk and explore the forest again.

meanings: To keep something with you or not let it go, like when you retain your favorite toy or a special memory in your mind.
examples: I try to retain all the important facts from our science lessons so I can do well on the tests.
When I read a good book, I want to retain the characters' names and their adventures in my memory.
My coach taught us how to retain our energy during the game by staying hydrated and taking short breaks.
If I retain my allowance money, I can save up for the new video game I really want.
It's important to retain the friendship we have by being kind and sharing with each other.

meanings: To stop working, usually because you are older and have saved enough money to take a break and enjoy life.
examples: My grandfather decided to retire after working at his job for over 40 years, so now he can spend more time with us.
After many years of playing soccer, my coach said he would retire and let someone else take over the team.
The teacher told us that she plans to retire next year, and we are all going to miss her fun lessons.
When animals get old, like elephants and turtles, they often retire from their busy lives in the wild and find a safe place to rest.
In the story, the brave knight chose to retire after saving the kingdom, so he could enjoy peaceful days in his garden.

meanings: To go back to how things were before, like when you change your mind about a game and want to play it the old way again.
examples: When I changed my drawing from a cat to a dog, I decided to revert it back to the original cat I liked better.
After trying a new video game, I chose to revert to my favorite one because it was more fun.
If my plants start to wilt, I can revert the watering schedule to help them grow strong again.
In our science project, we learned that some animals can revert to their baby forms if they are in danger.
When my friend and I disagreed about a game rule, we had to revert to the original rules we agreed on before.

meanings: To bring something back to life or to make it strong and active again, like when a plant grows back after being watered or when a fun game becomes popular again.
examples: We used water and sunlight to revive the wilting plant in our classroom garden.
The science club worked hard to revive the old computer so we could use it for our project.
After the rain, the flowers seemed to revive and bloom brighter than before in the park.
The teacher planned fun activities to revive our interest in reading during the book fair.
We decided to revive our favorite game by adding new rules and inviting more friends to play.

meanings: To make fun of someone in a mean way, often by laughing at them or making jokes that can hurt their feelings.
