examples: It’s not nice to ridicule someone for their ideas, even if you don’t agree with them.
When the teacher saw the kids ridicule their classmate, she reminded them to be kind to one another.
During the game, it hurt my feelings when some players started to ridicule me for making a mistake.
In the story, the main character faced ridicule from his classmates, but he learned to believe in himself.
We should always support our friends instead of using ridicule to make them feel bad about themselves.

meanings: Stiff and hard, so it can't bend or change easily, like a straight piece of metal or a strict rule that doesn’t allow for any differences.
examples: The table was so rigid that I couldn’t push it even an inch when I tried to move it.
My teacher explained that some rules are rigid, meaning they can't be changed no matter what.
The frozen pond looked beautiful, but I knew it was too rigid to walk on safely.
When building with blocks, if the structure is too rigid, it might break if someone bumps into it.
In science class, we learned that some materials are rigid, while others are flexible and can bend easily.

meanings: A riot is when a large group of people get together and act very loudly and angrily, often causing trouble and breaking things. It can happen when people are upset about something and want to show the...
examples: During the school assembly, the kids started a riot when the principal announced a surprise extra week of vacation.
In the book I read, a riot broke out in the town square when citizens demanded better rights and respect.
When the soccer game ended in a tie, some fans created a riot by shouting and throwing things onto the field.
The animals in the zoo seemed to cause a riot when the zookeepers brought in food, making a lot of noise and excitement.
At the carnival, the crowd turned into a riot when the main event was delayed, and everyone started to get restless.

meanings: A ripple is a small wave that moves across the surface of water, like when you throw a stone into a pond and see the little waves spreading out.
examples: When I dropped a pebble into the pond, it created a ripple that spread across the water.
As we watched the ducks swim, we noticed how their movements made small ripples on the lake.
In science class, we learned about how a ripple can travel across a pool of water after someone jumps in.
The wind blew gently over the surface of the lake, making tiny ripples that sparkled in the sunlight.
During the field trip, we saw how a single drop of rain can make a ripple in a puddle on the playground.

meanings: To wake someone up or make them more active; like when you shake a friend awake or get everyone excited to play a game.
examples: The loud alarm clock will rouse me from my sleep so I can get ready for school.
We need to rouse our team’s spirits if we want to win the soccer game this weekend.
The teacher tried to rouse our interest in science by showing us a cool experiment with bubbling vinegar.
When I read my favorite adventure book, it can rouse my imagination and make me dream of exploring new worlds.
The warm sunlight streaming through the window seemed to rouse the flowers in the garden to bloom brightly.

meanings: A route is a path or road that you take to get from one place to another, like the way you walk to school or drive to a friend's house.
examples: We took a different route to school today because there was a parade on our usual street.
During our nature hike, we followed a special route that led us to a beautiful waterfall.
When I play video games, I always try to find the quickest route to win the race.
For our field trip, the teacher showed us the best route to reach the museum without getting lost.
My dog loves to explore new routes in the park, sniffing every tree and bush along the way.

meanings: To saunter means to walk slowly and easily, like when you stroll through a park enjoying the scenery. It's a relaxed way to move, often just for fun.
examples: After lunch, we decided to saunter through the park, enjoying the flowers and birds singing.
On our way home from school, we always saunter past the ice cream shop, dreaming of our favorite flavors.
During our nature walk, we took our time to saunter along the path, looking for interesting bugs and plants.
My grandma and I like to saunter around the neighborhood after dinner, sharing stories and watching the sunset.
When the bell rang, I chose to saunter to my next class, savoring the time with my friends and chatting.

meanings: To burn your skin with very hot water or steam, which can hurt a lot.
examples: Be careful when pouring hot water for your tea, or you might scald your fingers.
In science class, we learned that steam can scald your skin if you're too close to it.
When I accidentally spilled hot soup on my hand, I felt a sharp pain from the scald.
The chef warned us not to touch the pot, as it could scald us if we weren't careful.
After the hot bath, I realized I had to wait a bit, so I wouldn't scald my skin when I got out.

meanings: Seldom means you don’t do something very often. For example, if you seldom go to the park, it means you go there only once in a while.
examples: I seldom eat dessert on weekdays because I want to save it for the weekend.
In science class, we seldom get to do experiments, but when we do, it's always exciting.
My dog seldom barks at strangers, so it surprises me when he does.
We seldom have snow in our town, but when it happens, we all rush outside to play.
I seldom finish my homework early, but today I got it done before dinner!

meanings: A sensation is a feeling that you get when something happens to your body, like when you touch something hot and feel pain, or when you eat something sweet and feel happy.
examples: When I touched the cold ice, I felt a strange sensation that made me giggle.
Reading an exciting book gives me a wonderful sensation that makes me want to keep turning the pages.
After running around outside, the warm sunshine felt like a cozy sensation on my skin.
When I tried the sour candy, the surprising sensation made my face scrunch up in a funny way.
The soft fur of the puppy brought me a happy sensation that made me smile from ear to ear.

meanings: To sever means to cut something apart or to break it so that it is no longer connected. For example, if you cut a piece of string in half, you sever it into two pieces.
examples: The gardener had to sever the dead branches from the tree so it could grow new leaves in the spring.
During art class, we learned how to sever the paper carefully to create beautiful shapes for our project.
When the rope started to fray, it was important to sever the weak part before using it for climbing.
In the science experiment, we had to sever the connection between the two wires to see what would happen.
The knight had to sever the dragon's tail in order to save the village from danger in the story we read.

meanings: Significant" means something that is very important or makes a big difference, like when you win a special award or when your friend really needs your help.
examples: Winning the science fair was a significant achievement for me because I worked really hard on my project.
The book we read in class had a significant lesson about friendship that made us all think.
My dad's promotion at work was a significant change for our family, and we celebrated with a special dinner.
Learning about the history of our town was significant because it helped us understand where we live better.
The coach told us that teamwork is significant in sports, and that's why we practice passing the ball together.

meanings: To slide smoothly and quietly along the ground, like how a snake moves without legs.
examples: The snake can slither quietly through the grass without making a sound.
In our science class, we watched a video of a lizard that can slither across the sand.
During our nature walk, we spotted a snail that seemed to slither slowly on the path.
When I pretend to be a snake, I like to slither around the living room like a real one.
The magician made a ribbon slither through his fingers as he performed his magic trick.

meanings: Moving very slowly or not having much energy, like when you're tired and don't feel like running around.
examples: After staying up late to finish my book, I felt sluggish and didn't want to get out of bed in the morning.
The turtle moved sluggishly across the sand, taking its time to reach the water.
During gym class, I felt sluggish and tired, but I still tried my best to keep up with my friends.
When it’s hot outside, I often feel sluggish and just want to relax in the shade with a cool drink.
My pet hamster was sluggish after eating too many treats, so I gave him some time to rest.

meanings: The snout is the part of an animal's face that sticks out, including the nose and mouth. Animals like dogs and pigs have snouts that help them smell and eat.
examples: The elephant used its long snout to pick up food from the ground and feed itself.
We saw a cartoon pig with a big, funny snout in the movie we watched last night.
When we visited the zoo, the kids were fascinated by the way the hippo splashed water with its snout.
In our science class, we learned that a dog’s snout helps it smell things much better than we can.
My little brother loves to pretend he’s a dinosaur, roaring and stomping with his pretend snout!

meanings: To soar means to fly high in the sky, like a bird or an airplane, often without flapping wings. It feels like gliding up into the air easily and gracefully.
examples: The eagle can soar high above the mountains, searching for food with its sharp eyes.
During the science fair, I watched my paper airplane soar across the gym, impressing everyone.
When I ride my bike down the hill, I feel like I can soar like a bird in the sky.
In art class, my creativity can soar when I use bright colors to express my feelings.
As the sun sets, the hot air balloon began to soar gently above the trees, looking beautiful in the sky.

meanings: Being alone and not with other people; it can feel peaceful or lonely, depending on how you feel about it.
examples: Sometimes, I enjoy a solitary walk in the park to think about my day and relax.
The solitary owl perched quietly on the branch, watching the world below as the sun set.
During the summer, I like to read solitary books in my room, lost in exciting adventures.
My dog doesn't like to be solitary; he always wants to be near me when I play.
In history class, we learned about a solitary explorer who traveled alone across the ocean to discover new lands.

meanings: Doing something all by yourself, without anyone helping or joining you. For example, if you sing a song by yourself, that’s a solo!
examples: I decided to complete my art project solo, so I could express my ideas without any distractions.
During the talent show, Mia sang a solo song that impressed everyone in the audience.
After school, I practiced my guitar solo in the living room to get ready for the concert.
In our science class, I chose to work solo on my project about the solar system because I wanted to focus deeply.
When we played soccer at recess, I took a solo shot at the goal and scored a point for my team!

meanings: Somber means something that is dark or serious, like a rainy day that makes you feel quiet or thoughtful. It can also describe a mood that is a bit sad or heavy.
examples: The sky looked somber as dark clouds gathered before the storm, making everyone rush inside.
During the somber ceremony, we remembered our brave soldiers who fought for our freedom.
The painting had somber colors that made me feel calm and thoughtful as I looked at it.
In the somber scene of the book, the hero was faced with a tough choice that changed his life.
My dog had a somber expression when I left for school, as if he really missed me.

meanings: Sparse" means that something is spread out and not crowded together, like when there are only a few trees in a big field.
examples: The forest was sparse in some areas, with only a few trees standing tall among the open spaces.
During the science project, we learned that desert plants are sparse because they need very little water to survive.
In the classroom, the posters were sparse on the walls, which made the room feel a little empty and plain.
My garden has sparse flowers this year because we didn't get enough rain in the spring to help them grow.
When we hiked up the mountain, we noticed that the wildlife was sparse, making it quiet and peaceful all around us.

meanings: A spectator is a person who watches a game, show, or event, like when you go to see your favorite sports team play. Spectators cheer, clap, and enjoy the excitement from the sidelines!
examples: The crowd of spectators cheered loudly as the soccer team scored a goal during the exciting match.
During the science fair, many spectators gathered to watch our robot perform its amazing tricks.
As a spectator at the basketball game, I felt the energy in the arena when the home team made a comeback.
My little brother was a curious spectator as he watched the fireworks light up the night sky on New Year's Eve.
The art exhibit attracted many spectators who admired the colorful paintings and sculptures created by local artists.

meanings: A stall is a small, open space where things are sold, like at a market, or it can mean to stop moving or to take a break from doing something.
examples: We visited the market and saw a stall filled with colorful fruits and vegetables.
During the science fair, I had to stall for time while my project finished cooling down.
At the carnival, my favorite stall sold delicious cotton candy and fun toys.
When my bike had a flat tire, I had to stall my friends while I fixed it.
The school book fair had a stall where we could buy cool bookmarks and stickers.

meanings: Steadfast means being very loyal and not changing your mind. It's like sticking by your friend’s side no matter what happens.
examples: My dog is steadfast, always waiting for me to come home from school every day.
During the soccer game, my teammates were steadfast, cheering each other on even when we were losing.
In the story, the hero was steadfast, never giving up on his quest to save the kingdom from danger.
My grandmother is steadfast in her love for our family, always supporting us no matter what happens.
The scientist was steadfast in her research, working hard every day to discover new things about space.

meanings: To make someone or something more active or excited, like when you play a fun game that makes you want to move and have fun.
examples: Reading exciting books can stimulate your imagination and help you think of new stories to write.
Playing team sports can stimulate your teamwork skills and make you a better player on the field.
When we learn about the stars and planets, it can stimulate our curiosity about space and science.
Gardening can stimulate a love for nature and teach you how to care for living things around you.
Doing puzzles can stimulate your brain and help you solve problems in a fun way.

meanings: Stupendous means something that is really amazing or surprising, like a giant roller coaster or a spectacular fireworks show.
examples: The fireworks show on New Year's Eve was so stupendous that everyone cheered and clapped with excitement.
When I read the stupendous book about space, I learned about black holes and distant galaxies.
Our science project on volcanoes was stupendous, and the teacher said it was one of the best she had ever seen.
I had a stupendous time at the birthday party, especially when we played games and ate cake with my friends.
The stupendous painting at the art museum made me feel like I was in a magical world filled with colors.

meanings: Something that happens after another thing, like when you eat lunch after your morning classes.
examples: After the storm passed, the subsequent sunshine made the flowers bloom beautifully in our garden.
We learned about dinosaurs in class, and in the subsequent lesson, we studied how they became extinct.
I read a book about space, and in the subsequent chapter, the author explained black holes.
The soccer game was exciting, and the subsequent match next week will be even more thrilling!
After we finished our science experiment, we wrote down the subsequent results in our notebooks.

meanings: Substantial means something that is big, important, or has a lot of value, like a large piece of cake or a big accomplishment.
examples: The science project we worked on together had a substantial impact on how we understood the water cycle.
After studying for weeks, I felt a substantial improvement in my math skills before the big test.
The library has a substantial collection of books that can help us learn about different countries and cultures.
During the game, my team made a substantial effort to work together and score points.
The birthday cake was substantial enough to feed all my friends and family at the party.

meanings: To suffocate means to stop someone or something from getting air, which can make it hard to breathe. It can also mean to feel trapped and unable to grow or succeed.
examples: If you cover a plastic bottle completely, it can suffocate the air inside, making it hard to breathe.
When we put too many plants in a small pot, they can suffocate each other and not grow well.
During the science experiment, we learned that a fire can suffocate without oxygen and go out.
My puppy got scared and tried to hide under the blanket, and I worried he might suffocate in there.
If you hold your breath for too long, you might feel like you're going to suffocate and need to breathe again.

meanings: The summit is the very top part of a mountain or hill, like the highest place you can stand. It's also used to describe reaching the best or most important point in something, like winning a big award...
examples: The hikers reached the summit of the mountain and celebrated with snacks while enjoying the beautiful view.
In our science project, we learned that the summit of a volcano is where the lava comes out during an eruption.
After years of practice, she finally reached the summit of her swimming goals by winning a gold medal.
The school's art club created a mural that represents the summit of creativity in our community.
In the story, the brave knight climbed to the summit of the tallest tower to rescue the princess.

meanings: Better or higher in quality than something else; for example, a superior player is better at a game than others.
examples: The basketball team practiced every day, which made them superior to the other teams in the league.
In science class, we learned that some plants are superior at surviving in dry places compared to others.
My sister thinks that her drawing skills are superior to mine, but I believe everyone has their own unique style.
The book I read was superior to the movie because it had more exciting details and interesting characters.
In our school, the fifth graders are often seen as superior because they get to help the younger kids with their reading.

meanings: To survive means to stay alive and keep going, even when things are really hard or dangerous.
examples: The campers learned how to build a shelter so they could survive in the woods if they got lost.
After the storm, the animals in the forest worked together to find food and survive until spring.
In the book, the hero had to use his wits to survive in a magical land filled with challenges.
During our science project, we learned that some plants can survive even in the harshest desert conditions.
When we played the survival game, we had to gather resources and work as a team to survive the challenges.

meanings: To suspend something means to pause it for a while, like when your teacher stops a game during recess until everyone is ready to play again.
examples: The teacher decided to suspend our science experiment until next week because we needed more time to prepare.
During the storm, the city had to suspend all outdoor activities for safety reasons.
My favorite soccer game was suspended because it started raining heavily, so we went inside to play board games instead.
The library will suspend all late fees for one month to encourage kids to read more books.
When the electricity went out, we had to suspend our video game tournament until it came back on.

meanings: To taper means to slowly get thinner or smaller at one end, like a pencil that is sharpened to a point.
examples: As the candle burned down, it started to taper, becoming thinner and thinner until it was almost gone.
When we made our paper airplanes, we had to taper the wings to help them fly better in the air.
The artist decided to taper the bottom of the sculpture so it would stand more firmly on the table.
In science class, we learned that the shape of a cone tapers from a wide base to a pointed tip at the top.
When I cut the ends of the birthday hat, I made sure to taper them so they looked nice and sharp.

meanings: A task is something you need to do, like a chore or homework, that helps you learn or get things done.
examples: My teacher gave us a task to write a story about our favorite animal for homework.
After school, my dad asked me to help him with a task to clean the garage.
For our science project, we each had a task to research different animals and present what we learned.
During art class, our task was to create a painting that showed what makes us happy.
I felt proud when I completed my task of organizing my books and toys in my room.

meanings: To taunt someone means to make fun of them in a mean way, often by teasing or saying hurtful things. It's like poking fun at someone to make them feel bad.
examples: During recess, some kids started to taunt the new student because he didn't know how to play soccer yet.
It's not nice to taunt someone for their mistakes; we should help each other instead.
When I accidentally dropped my lunch tray, some classmates tried to taunt me, but my friend stood up for me.
In the story, the bully would often taunt the hero, but eventually, the hero proved that kindness is stronger than mean words.
At the basketball game, the fans began to taunt the other team, but our coach reminded us to play fair and be respectful.

meanings: To teem means to be full of many things or to have a lot of something moving around. For example, a pond can teem with fish, meaning there are lots of fish swimming in it.
examples: The pond by our school teems with frogs and dragonflies during the warm spring months.
In the summer, our garden teems with colorful flowers and buzzing bees that help it grow.
The library teems with exciting books that take you on adventures to far-off places.
After the rain, the forest teems with new life, and you can hear birds singing everywhere.
At the soccer game, the field teems with players running and cheering for their teams to win.

meanings: A tempest is a very strong storm with lots of wind, rain, or even snow. It can be scary because it makes everything shake and can cause big waves in the ocean.
examples: The tempest raged outside, making it impossible for us to play soccer during recess.
In the story, a brave sailor faces a fierce tempest while trying to find his way home.
Our science teacher showed us a video of a tempest, explaining how storms can form and cause damage.
As the tempest passed, we saw rainbows in the sky and realized nature can be both beautiful and wild.
During the tempest, the trees swayed and the wind howled, creating a spooky atmosphere at night.

meanings: To end something or make it stop, like when you turn off a video game or finish a book.
examples: The teacher decided to terminate the spelling quiz early because many students were feeling sick.
If you don’t water your plants, they might terminate their growth and stop getting bigger.
The coach had to terminate practice when it started raining heavily and lightning appeared in the sky.
In the story, the hero had to terminate the villain's plan to take over the world and save everyone.
When the timer goes off, it will terminate the game, and we will see who has the most points.

meanings: Terse means using very few words to say something. It's like giving a quick answer without extra details.
examples: The teacher gave a terse explanation of the math problem, so we quickly understood how to solve it.
When I asked my dad if he liked my drawing, his terse answer was simply, "Yes."
After the game, my coach's terse advice helped us improve our strategy for the next match.
My sister sent a terse text saying she would be late for dinner, so we started without her.
The book had a terse ending that made me think about what would happen next.

meanings: To stop someone from getting what they want or to make sure something doesn’t happen. For example, if you try to finish a puzzle and someone knocks it over, they thwart your plan to complete it.
examples: The superhero worked hard to thwart the villain's plan to steal all the candy from the store.
When the rain started, it tried to thwart our picnic plans, but we found a nice spot under a big tree.
The teacher had to thwart the students' attempts to sneak snacks during the test.
In the soccer game, our amazing goalie was able to thwart the other team's shots on goal.
The clever fox managed to thwart the farmer's traps and escape into the woods.

meanings: Being tolerant means being okay with other people's different opinions, ideas, or ways of doing things, even if they are not the same as yours. It’s about being nice and accepting everyone for who the...
examples: Being tolerant means we can accept our friends even when they have different opinions about our favorite games.
In art class, it's important to be tolerant of each other's styles, so we can all learn from one another.
My teacher is very tolerant, allowing us to express our ideas during class discussions without judgment.
When my little brother plays with my toys, I try to be tolerant because I know he just wants to have fun too.
In nature, some animals are tolerant of different climates, which helps them survive in many places around the world.

meanings: To make something fall over or tip over, like when you push a tower of blocks and it falls down.
examples: The strong wind was so powerful that it could easily topple the tall trees in the park.
When we stacked the blocks too high, they began to wobble and eventually toppled over.
In the game of Jenga, players must carefully remove blocks without causing the tower to topple.
During the science experiment, we watched how the weight of the marble could topple the paper cup when placed on top.
The little boy tried to balance his toy cars on top of each other, but they toppled with the slightest touch.

meanings: To transform means to change something into a different shape or look, like how a caterpillar changes into a butterfly.
examples: When we mix paint colors, we can transform plain white into bright and exciting shades.
The caterpillar will transform into a beautiful butterfly after it goes through metamorphosis.
In science class, we learned how heat can transform ice into water and then into steam.
Reading a good book can transform your imagination and take you to amazing places.
Our classroom will transform into a winter wonderland for the holiday party next week!

meanings: To translate means to change words from one language to another so that people can understand them better. For example, when someone speaks in Spanish and you say it in English, you are translating.
examples: In our class, we learned how to translate words from English to Spanish using a fun worksheet.
When I read a book in French, I used a dictionary to help me translate the tricky parts into English.
My brother speaks Mandarin, so he helps me translate when I want to understand his favorite songs.
During our history lesson, we worked together to translate ancient texts into modern language for our project.
At the science fair, I had to translate my speech into simple words so everyone could understand my experiment.

meanings: A tremor is a small shaking or movement, like when you feel a little vibration after a loud noise or during an earthquake. It can make the ground feel wobbly for a moment.
examples: During the science lesson, we learned that a tremor can happen when the earth shakes during an earthquake.
When I was playing outside, I felt a slight tremor in the ground, and I looked around to see what was happening.
In our history class, we studied how ancient buildings sometimes collapsed due to tremors caused by earthquakes long ago.
My dog started barking when he felt a tremor from the thunderstorm, and I knew a storm was coming.
After the tremor shook our house, we all gathered safely in the living room to make sure everyone was okay.

meanings: Tropical means relating to warm places near the equator, where it is hot and often has lots of plants and animals, like in rainforests or on beautiful beaches.
examples: The tropical rainforest is home to many colorful animals and plants that you can’t find anywhere else in the world.
During our science project, we learned that tropical regions have warm weather and heavy rainfall all year round.
In our geography class, we looked at a map and found the tropical areas near the equator where it’s always sunny.
My favorite book is about a tropical island where a group of kids discovers hidden treasures and makes new friends.
When we visited the zoo, we saw tropical birds with bright feathers and learned about their natural habitats.

meanings: Hard to carry or manage because it is too big or awkward in shape.
examples: The large, unwieldy box was hard to carry to the school assembly, and we needed two people to lift it.
My art project was so unwieldy that I had trouble fitting it through the classroom door without knocking over other things.
During the science fair, my unwieldy volcano model spilled baking soda everywhere because it was too big to handle easily.
The unwieldy backpack made it difficult for me to run to catch the bus after school.
When we went camping, the unwieldy tent took a long time to set up because it had so many parts.

meanings: Upbringing is how parents and family help teach a child about life, values, and behavior while growing up. It includes the love, rules, and lessons they give you.
examples: My parents taught me the importance of kindness during my upbringing, so I always try to help others.
In my upbringing, my family encouraged me to read books, which helped me learn new things every day.
My friend's upbringing was different from mine because her family loves to travel and explore new places together.
The lessons I learned from my upbringing, like being honest and respectful, help me make good choices at school.
During our science project, I realized that my upbringing taught me to be curious and ask lots of questions.

meanings: Urban" means related to a city where many people live, and there are lots of buildings, roads, and shops.
examples: The urban park near my house has a playground and lots of tall buildings around it.
In our science class, we learned how urban areas have more pollution than rural areas because of all the cars and factories.
My family took a trip to an urban museum where we saw cool exhibits about history and art.
During the summer, I enjoy visiting my cousins who live in an urban neighborhood filled with shops and restaurants.
The urban library is a great place to find books and meet friends after school for our study group.

meanings: Vertical means standing straight up and down, like a tree or a flagpole. If you imagine drawing a line that goes from the ground straight up to the sky, that's vertical!
examples: The tall building stood vertical against the blue sky, making it look very impressive from the ground.
In gym class, we learned how to do a vertical jump to see how high we could reach.
When we built our model rocket, we made sure it was vertical so it would fly straight up into the air.
The tree in our backyard grew vertical, stretching its branches high towards the sunlight.
In art class, we painted a vertical mural on the wall that showed a beautiful landscape.

meanings: Something that can be seen with your eyes; if it's visible, you can look at it and notice it around you.
examples: The stars are visible in the night sky when there are no clouds to block our view.
During the science fair, my project was visible from across the room because I used bright colors.
In autumn, the colorful leaves become visible on the trees, making the park look beautiful.
When the teacher turned off the lights, the glow-in-the-dark stickers became visible on the walls.
The rainbow was visible after the rain stopped, and we all rushed outside to see it.

meanings: A vow is a promise you make to yourself or someone else to do something important. It's like saying, "I will definitely do this!" and meaning it with all your heart.
examples: I made a vow to always help my little sister with her homework after school.
During the team meeting, we all took a vow to support each other during the big game this weekend.
After reading the book about friendship, I decided to vow to always be kind to others.
At the start of the new year, I made a vow to practice my guitar every day to get better.
In the school assembly, the students made a vow to keep our playground clean and safe for everyone.

meanings: A voyage is a long trip taken over water, like on a ship, or sometimes into space. It's an exciting adventure where you explore new places!
examples: Our class took a virtual voyage through space to learn about the planets and stars in our science lesson.
In the story, the brave knight went on a long voyage across the sea to rescue the princess from a dragon.
During summer vacation, my family plans to go on a voyage to a tropical island where we can swim and explore.
The explorers set sail on a dangerous voyage in search of new lands and treasures, just like in the history book we read.
We imagined a fantastic voyage in our art project, creating colorful drawings of underwater creatures and ships sailing through the ocean.

meanings: To waddle means to walk in a funny way, like a penguin, with short steps and a bit of side-to-side movement.
examples: The duck began to waddle across the pond, making everyone giggle at its silly movements.
When my little brother puts on his oversized shoes, he starts to waddle around the house like a penguin.
After eating too many cookies, my dog started to waddle as he walked back to his favorite spot on the couch.
In gym class, we had a funny race where we had to waddle like ducks to the finish line.
I watched the baby geese waddle behind their mother as they explored the grassy park.

meanings: A wilderness is a wild area of land where plants and animals live freely, without people building houses or farms. It’s like nature's playground, full of trees, rivers, and wildlife.
examples: The wilderness is a great place to explore nature and see animals like deer and foxes in their natural habitat.
In science class, we learned that the wilderness is important for keeping our planet healthy and full of life.
My family goes camping in the wilderness every summer, and we enjoy hiking and roasting marshmallows by the campfire.
The book I read told a story about a brave girl who survived in the wilderness after getting lost during a hike.
During our field trip, we visited a wilderness area where we saw tall trees, flowing rivers, and lots of different plants.

meanings: To wither means to become dry and weak, like a plant that hasn't had enough water and starts to look sad and unhealthy.
examples: The beautiful flowers in the garden began to wither after we forgot to water them for a whole week.
When leaves fall from trees in autumn, they can wither and turn brown before winter arrives.
If you leave a sandwich out in the sun, it will wither and become dry and unappetizing.
The old book on the shelf started to wither, losing its pages and becoming hard to read over time.
As the sun set, the once vibrant colors of the sky began to wither into soft shades of gray.

meanings: To yearn means to really want something or to miss something a lot, like when you wish you could see a friend who lives far away.
examples: I yearn to visit the ocean because I love the sound of the waves and building sandcastles.
During the summer, I yearn for days filled with sunshine so I can ride my bike with my friends.
As I read the adventure book, I yearn to explore faraway lands like the brave heroes in the story.
When I see my friends playing soccer, I yearn to join them and show off my new skills.
After watching the science documentary, I yearn to learn more about outer space and the stars.
